{{Multiple issues|{{COI|date=July 2009}}{{orphan|date=February 2009}}{{refimprove|date=July 2009}}}} {{Infobox company |name = Eye Level Learning |logo = Eye Level Learning Logo.png |logo_size = 220 |type = [[Children's Education]] |foundation = 1976 |location = Seoul, Republic of Korea (Global HQ); [[Ridgefield Park, New Jersey]], United States |industry = [[Education]], [[Tutoring]] |key_people = [[Dr. Young Joong Kang]]: Founder and Chairman |homepage = {{URL|https://www.myeyelevel.com}} }}
'''Eye Level Learning''', formerly known as '''E.nopi''', offers supplementary educational programs from [[Daekyo]]. The name "Eye Level Learning" is used internationally whilst in [[South Korea]], where [[Daekyo]] is headquartered, it is named "Noonnoppi" ({{korean|hangul=눈높이}}) meaning "eye level".
Established in 1976, Daekyo provides a systematic learning method developed by Dr. Young Joong Kang. The program consists of Eye Level Math, which includes Basic and Critical Thinking Math, Eye Level English which includes four main concepts (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) and Eye Level Korean.
Eye Level has centers and student enrollment throughout North America and Asia. More than 2.5 million children in 25 countries have benefited from the Eye Level program. Eye Level Learning centers are located around the world.<ref>[https://www.myeyelevel.com/Global/English/ List of all Eye Level Learning franchises by country]. Find a learning center</ref> Eye Level Franchise provides its franchisees with thorough training and comprehensive ongoing support.
==Academics== ===Mathematics=== Eye Level Math has two main sections: Basic Thinking Math and Critical Thinking Math. In Basic Thinking Math, students focus on the arithmetic part of mathematics (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division). In Critical Thinking Math, students focus on patterns and relationships, geometry, problem solving, measurement and reasoning. Students are assigned to their levels based on test results, not by their grade levels. The "eye level" name means to look at the problem from the children's level. A teacher should get down to the child's level and see the problem to better assist them in solving it.
===English=== Eye Level English focuses on four main fundamental skills: Reading, Listening, Writing, and Speaking. Within the program, students have the ability to reinforce their English skills with such activities as Active Listening, writing prompts, and phonics.
===Chinese=== Eye Level Chinese (Only in [[China]]) is reviewed by Beijing University. It focuses on listening, speaking, reading and writing. They learn about Chinese characters by role-playing, songs, games and other engaging activities.
===Supplemental Education Services=== Eye Level works through the [[No Child Left Behind Act]]. Eye Level offers tutoring known as [[Supplemental Education Services]]. Eye Level is an approved provider in the following U.S. states: California,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sacramento/news/2013/05/01/eye-level-learning-center-franchises.html|title=Eye Level learning center franchise making big push into region|date=May 1, 2013|publisher=bizjournals.com|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref> Connecticut, Illinois,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/morton-grove/news/ct-mgc-eye-level-literacy-awards-tl-0827-20150817-story.html|title=Morton Grove's Eye Level Learning participates in annual literary competition|date=August 17, 2015|publisher=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref> New Jersey,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mebs.gmnews.com/node/78855|title=gmnews.com|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref> New York,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2013/04/03/nyregion/cram-schools-no-longer-just-an-asian-pursuit.html?_r=0&referrer=|title=Centers See New Faces Seeking Test Prep|date=April 2, 2013|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref> Pennsylvania and Texas.

[[File:Krul.svg|thumb|Krul]]A '''flourish of approval''' or ''krul'' is a mostly Dutch [[symbol]] used for grading schoolwork or to show that one has seen and agreed with a paragraph. The ''krul'' first appeared in the early 19th century together with the rising bureaucracy in the [[Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Waar komt het vandaan?|url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2011/02/09/waar-komt-het-en-vandaan-het-11995186-a946165|website=NRC|language=Dutch|accessdate=2018-05-23}}</ref> Historians believe that the symbol is derived from a hastily written 'g' which would stand for good (''goed'') or seen (''gezien''). The symbol is rarely used outside of the Netherlands apart from (former) Dutch colonies like [[Indonesia]], [[South Africa]], the [[Netherlands Antilles]] and [[Suriname]].
Despite its wide usage throughout the country and its former colonies there is no unicode symbol for this.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to make a “krul” (unofficial Dutch symbol for OK)|url=https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/313281/how-to-make-a-krul-unofficial-dutch-symbol-for-ok|website=Stackexchange|language=English|accessdate=2018-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What is the name or Unicode for this symbol (similar to ₰, Dutch, called Krul)|url=https://graphicdesign.stackexchange.com/questions/58320/what-is-the-name-or-unicode-for-this-symbol-similar-to-₰-dutch-called-krul|website=Stackexchange|language=English|accessdate=2018-05-30}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Symbols]] [[Category:Education in the Netherlands]]

page.title: Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender Round Table

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=December 2013}} The '''Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender Round Table''' ('''GLBTRT''') is part of the [[American Library Association]] and is dedicated to serving and meeting the information needs of [[LGBT]] individuals.<ref>[http://www.ala.org/glbtrt/about/bylaws GLBTRT Bylaws & Mission Statement | Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual & Transgender Round Table (GLBTRT)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The Round Table also serves library professionals who are LGBT. One of the core values of the ALA is to reflect the diversity of the United States by "providing a full spectrum of resources and services to the communities [they] serve."<ref>[http://www.ala.org/advocacy/intfreedom/statementspols/corevalues#diversity Core Values of Librarianship | Advocacy, Legislation & Issues<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The GLBTRT provides an online toolkit for library professionals who want to promote or display LGBT materials. The toolkit also explains how to deal with complaints from the public.<ref>[http://www.ala.org/advocacy/intfreedom/iftoolkits/glbttoolkit/glbttoolkit Out in the Library: Materials, Displays and Services for the Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, and Transgender Community | Advocacy, Legislation & Issues<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1970, the GLBTRT was formed. It was originally called the Task Force on Gay Liberation, and it was formed within the American Library Association. It is the oldest LGBT professional organization in the United States. [[Barbara Gittings]] became its coordinator in 1971.
In the early 1970s, the GLBTRT (then called the Task Force on Gay Liberation) campaigned to have books about the gay liberation movement at the Library of Congress reclassified from HQ 71–471 ("Abnormal Sexual Relations, Including Sexual Crimes"). In 1972, after receiving a letter requesting the reclassification, the Library of Congress agreed to make the shift, reclassifying those books into a newly created category, HQ 76.5 ("Homosexuality, Lesbianism—Gay Liberation Movement, Homophile Movement").
In 1971 the GLBTRT created the first award for GLBT books, the [[Stonewall Book Award]], which celebrates books of exceptional merit that relate to LGBT issues.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ala.org/glbtrt/award Stonewall Book Awards | Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual & Transgender Round Table (GLBTRT)<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150822082408/http://www.ala.org/glbtrt/award |date=2015-08-22 }}</ref> ''[[Patience and Sarah]]'' by [[Alma Routsong]] (pen name Isabel Miller) was the first winner.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In 1992, American Libraries published a photo of the GLBTRT (then called the Gay and Lesbian Task Force) on the cover of its July/August issue, drawing both criticism and praise from the library world. Some commenters called the cover "in poor taste" and accused American Libraries of "glorifying homosexuality," while others were supportive of the move. Christine Williams, who wrote an essay about the controversy surrounding the cover, concluded that in the mid-90s, the library world was "not an especially welcoming place to gays and lesbians."
In 2010, the GLBTRT announced a new committee, the Over the Rainbow Committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.glbtrt.ala.org/overtherainbow/|title=Over the Rainbow Books|last=|first=|date=|website=Over the Rainbow Books|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=August 29, 2016}}</ref> This committee annually compiles a bibliography of books that show the GLBT community in a favorable light and reflects the interests of adults. The bibliographies provide guidance to libraries in the selection of positive GLBT materials.The bibliographies are split by age with the Rainbow Book List providing material for children and teens, and the Over the Rainbow Book List supplying titles for adults.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archives.library.illinois.edu/ala/lots-love-revolutionary-non-revolutionary-kind-history-glbt-round-table/|title="Lots of Love (of both the revolutionary and non-revolutionary kind)": the History of the ALA’s GLBT Round Table|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2015, ALA's Office for Diversity, Literacy, and Outreach Services and the GLBTRT assumed oversight of GBLT Book month which occurs annually in June.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=70642|title=Political Notebook: Library group takes lead in promoting LGBT books|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Their efforts to increase visibility of GLBT material included promoting the Rainbow Books and the Over the Rainbow Books lists, marketing on social media using a specific hashtag, and providing resources for libraries to participate in GLBT Book month.
==See also== * [[Libraries and the LGBT community]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.ala.org/glbtrt/}} * [http://www.ala.org/glbtrt/newsletter/collection GLBTRT Newsletter ]
[[Category:American Library Association]] [[Category:LGBT and education]] [[Category:LGBT organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Librarianship and human rights]] [[Category:1970 establishments in the United States]]

page.title: Gifted Education Resource Institute, Purdue University

revision.comment: replaced: Development → development, Programs → programs, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Master’s degree → master's degree; other cap, punct using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Gifted Education Resource Institute (GERI)''' is a multidimensional center dedicated to the study, discovery, and development of human potential. It was founded by [[John F. Feldhusen]] in 1977 and is situated in the College of Education, [[Purdue University]] in West Lafayette, Indiana. GERI’s mission is holistic development of [[Gifted education|giftedness]], creativity, and talent among individuals throughout their lifespan. This is accomplished through enrichment programs for talented youth, graduate programs for future scholars and leaders, professional development and coursework for educators, and ongoing research on the psychology of giftedness, creativity, and talent development. GERI faculty and staff work with [[K–12 (education)|P-12]] educators in developing and improving services for gifted, creative, and talented children, as well as training school teachers and administrators in [[gifted education]]. In addition, GERI has developed several programs for talented youth. The Super Saturday program, a six-week enrichment program, was created in the spring of 1976. In 1977, GERI began Summer Residential Camps, aimed at providing a preview of college life to talented students.
__TOC__
== Talent development programs ==
The talent development programs at GERI help talented students explore their areas of interest in a college atmosphere where they study topics typically not offered in school. Together, students learn challenging content and create meaningful projects in which they apply their learning in new and relevant ways. Participation in GERI programs provides students in-depth and clear understanding of the fields they might like to pursue. Many students attend GERI Talent Development Programs for multiple years.
=== Summer residential camps ===
Every summer, for over 34 years, GERI has engaged gifted, creative, and talented students from across the country and around the world in residential camps designed to stimulate their imagination and expand their abilities. Students who have completed grades 5 through 12 live in campus residence halls, take challenging courses, and participate in engaging recreational activities. GERI offers three programs each summer. * Comet, 1 week sessions: For students who have completed grade 5-6. * Star, 2 week sessions: For students who have completed grades 7-8. * Pulsar, 2 week sessions: For students who have completed grades 9-12. The application process includes: * Completing the application form. * Creating a one-to two-page essay or alternative media (such as a Web site, PowerPoint presentation, or art portfolio) that addresses the applicant’s desire and motivation to participate. * Submitting evidence of notable ability, achievement, or involvement in the areas of study as detailed in the program brochure. Such evidence can include grades, test scores, letters of recommendation, and awards.
=== Super Summer and Super Saturday programs === The Super Summer and Super Saturday programs are two enrichment programs designed to meet the needs of academically, creatively, and artistically gifted students from Pre-Kindergarten (age 4) through grade 8. The courses include science, technology, engineering, mathematics, visual and performing arts, as well as original interdisciplinary studies. Super Saturday is offered both fall and spring semesters for six Saturdays, and Super Summer is offered week days during the summer for two, one-week sessions. Research on these programs found that students had positive experiences, learned new, above-grade-level concepts, and participated in interactive learning.
== Graduate programs == === Ph.D. and master's ===
The internationally recognized [[Ph.D.]] and master's degree programs in gifted, creative, and talented studies attract students from across the country and around the world. Working closely with faculty scholars as mentors, students prepare for productive leadership roles in research, teaching, and program development. Funding may be available to support exceptional students pursuing full-time Ph.D. study.
=== Licensure ===
The accredited [[licensure]] program is available online and on campus for teachers interested in adding a high-ability license to their Indiana teaching credentials or as a certificate in gifted, creative, and talented studies for educators in other states and countries. In this program, educators develop the knowledge and skills to meet the cognitive, affective, and social needs of gifted, creative and talented learners. They learn to how to develop and differentiate curriculum and instruction; and they prepare for leadership and teaching roles in working with and developing programs for gifted, creative, and talented students
== Research ==
The faculty and graduate students at GERI engage in cutting-edge research that informs and influences theory and practice. Some examples include: * Total School Cluster Grouping Model * Purdue Three-Stage Model * Theory of Personal Talent * Developing talent in the [[STEM fields|STEM]] disciplines * Applying gifted education know-how to improve general education * Understanding social and affective needs * Investigating students’ perceptions of their learning experiences * Studying [[twice-exceptional]] learners * Recognizing and developing talent among underserved populations and in non-traditional areas
== Professional development ==
Faculty and staff conduct professional development related to their research using online, on-site, and campus-based delivery methods, engaging educators from across the [[United States]] and from schools worldwide.
== References ==
[http://purdue.edu/geri GERI official website, Purdue University]
[http://www.jkcf.org Jack Kent Cooke Foundation]
[http://www.nagc.org/ National Association for Gifted Children]
[[Category:Gifted education]] [[Category:Alternative education]] [[Category:Summer camps in the United States]] [[Category:Middle States Commission on Secondary Schools]]

revision.comment: clean up, url redundant with jstor, and/or remove accessdate if no url using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
In English-language education, '''History of the English language''' ('''HEL''') is a commonly required class for students in [[English studies]] and [[Education theory|Education]], though in the nineteenth and early twentieth century it was often required of all US college students.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Baugh|first=Albert C.|year=1962|title=Historical Linguistics and the Teacher of English|journal=[[College English]]|volume=24|issue=2|pages=106–10|jstor=373743}}</ref>
==Content==
Since HEL is often the only linguistics class required of English majors and Education students, it usually includes a basic introduction to linguistic concepts and theories (on phonetics, dialects, language families, etc.) as well as the historical stages of English--[[Old English]], [[Middle English]], [[Early Modern English]], and [[Modern English]].
Among the topics which may be taught in HEL are the following: origin and development of the language; vocabulary and etymology; meaning and expression; the role of reference books and dictionaries; varieties of spoken English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conted.ox.ac.uk/courses/details.php?id=Q100-38|title=History of the English Language|date=2002–2013|publisher=[[University of Oxford]]|accessdate=25 January 2013}}</ref>
==History and place in the curriculum==
The need for HEL, as perceived by college professors and (English) department heads, was found to vary widely in a poll of department heads done in 1952. The poll asked heads to comment on the selection of language courses they'd require an MA candidate who applies for a teaching position to have taken; of 46 heads, 20 marked HEL, more than any other option (including advanced grammar, Old English, Chaucer, etc.). The author of the study noted that at the time no graduate courses in language study were required for the MA programs at many notable institutions, including Cornell, Johns Hopkins, Ohio State, and Penn State.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lee|first=Donald W|year=1952|title=English Language Studies and the M. A. Program|journal=[[College English]]|volume=14|issue=3|pages=164–66|jstor=372130}}</ref> The occasional passionate plea is made to promote HEL—J. E. Graves notes in a 1956 article in ''[[College English]]'' that proper courses in HEL are necessary for any future English teacher, and bemoans the perceived shoving aside of "language study in high school with non-rigorous semantics and 'learning situations.'"<ref>{{cite journal|last=Graves|first=J. E.|year=1956|title=Training English Teachers|journal=[[College English]]|volume=17|issue=8|jstor=495707}}</ref> One such plea came in 1961 from [[Albert C. Baugh]], professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania and author of ''A History of the English Language'',<ref name=kent>{{cite journal|last=Kent|first=Ronald G.|year=1936|title=Rev. of Baugh, ''A History of the English Language''|journal=[[Language (journal)|Language]]|volume=12|issue=1|pages=72–75|jstor=409029|doi=10.2307/409029}}</ref><ref name=bloomfield>{{cite journal|last=Bloomfield|first=Morton C.|year=1958|title=Rev. of Baugh, ''A History of the English Language''|journal=[[Journal of English and Germanic Philology]]|volume=57|issue=4|page=796|jstor=27707189}}</ref> who "justified" HEL by arguing that it teaches skills necessary for teachers of literature who often have students read older texts (Baugh cites Shakespeare throughout), including etymology (and the history of word changes), pronunciation and accentuation, and grammar and idiom.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Baugh|first=Albert C.|year=1962|title=Historical Linguistics and the Teacher|journal=[[College English]]|volume=24|issue=2|pages=106–10|jstor=373743}}</ref>
Many, though by no means all, scholars of education suggest the importance of HEL. Marcia Henry, taking the [[Orton-Gillingham]] approach for dyslexic children as a structural starting point, argues that teaching the subject aids students in decoding and spelling.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Henry|first=Marcia K.|year=1998|title=Beyond Phonics: Integrated Decoding and Spelling Instruction Based on Word Origin and Structure|journal=[[Annals of Dyslexia]]|volume=38|pages=258–75|url=http://ld4elementaryliteracy.edublogs.org/files/2008/07/beyondphonics.pdf|doi=10.1007/bf02648260}}</ref>
In the field of English education, a field now often referred to as English Language Arts in which HEL is often required, the position of history of the English language is tenuous: it is not universally acknowledged that elementary and high-school students need to be taught anything about the subject. James Ney, a linguist at Arizona State University, argues that the shift in contemporary linguistics toward [[transformational grammar]] has taken attention away from historical linguistics. Ney's study of high-school textbooks suggested that history of English only takes up a minute amount of coverage; if it is there at all, it pertains to etymology and dictionary usage. Though some curriculum proposals (some of which very ambitious; Ney singles out the 1968 Atlanta Regional Curriculum Project) did promote a more rigorous study of the subject in elementary and high school, no discernible impact seems to have been made on actual school curricula.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ney|first=James W.|editor=James Flood|others=Diane Lapp, James R. Squire, Julie M. Jensen|title=Handbook of Research on Teaching the English Language Arts|edition=2|year=2003|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum|location=Mahwah|isbn=9780805845181|pages=717–20|chapter=Teaching the Roots of Modern English: The History of the Language in the Language Arts Class}}</ref>
==Notable textbooks== <!-- (earliest known edition listed). --really? --> * [[John Algeo|Algeo, John]]: ''The Origins and Development of the English Language'' ** 6th ed., 2010 ([[Cengage Learning|Wadsworth]]), a continuation of the book of the same title written by Thomas Pyles in the 1960s. Intermediate editions were published as "Pyles and Algeo" * Baugh, Albert Croll and Thomas Cable: ''A History of the English Language'' ** 6th ed., 2013 ([[Longman]]); from the 3rd ed., 1978, continues the same title by Baugh ** 1st ed., 1935 ([[D. Appleton & Company|D. Appleton-Century Company]]), Baugh<ref name=kent/><ref name=bloomfield/><ref>[http://lccn.loc.gov/35008385 "A history of the English language"] (first edition). Library of Congress Catalog Record. Retrieved 2013-09-14.</ref> * Hogg, Richard Hogg and David Denison: ''A History of the English Language'' ** 1st ed., 2008 ([[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge UP]]) * Millward, C.M. and Mary Hayes: ''A Biography of the English Language'' ** 3rd ed., 2011 (Wadsworth), a continuation of the book of the same title by Millward (2nd, 1996)
==References== {{Reflist |25em }}
{{Portal|English|Language|Linguistics}}

page.title: Institute of Public Administration and Management

revision.text:
{{Infobox_University |name= Institute of Public Administration and Management |image= |motto= |established= 1980 |principal= Professor Ekundayo J. D. Thompson |city= [[Freetown]] |country= [[Sierra Leone]] |campus= A. J. Momoh Street & George Street |students= |colours= |type= [[public university|Public]] |affiliations= [[University of Sierra Leone]] |website= [http://www.ipam.usl.edu.sl/ www.usl.ipam.edu.sl] }}
The '''Institute of Public Administration and Management''' ('''IPAM''') is an institute of the University of Sierra Leone. It operates like other constituent colleges of the [[University of Sierra Leone]], under the authority of the University Senate and the University Court. IPAM is in the centre of Freetown at AJ Momoh Street, Tower Hill, close to the British Council, Statistics Sierra Leone, the West African Examination Council (WAEC) and the National Fire Force headquarters. The institute has four departments offering a range of business, information technology, finance and public administration courses to the public.
==Establishment==
The establishment of IPAM can be traced to 1970. It came as a result of a government white paper on education which proposed the closure of the Civil Service Training College. The responsibility for the training of middle- and upper-level staff was transferred to [[Fourah Bay College]] and that of the clerical cadre to the Freetown Technical Institute.
Subsequent review by the World Bank suggested the need for a more specialised establishment in public administration and management. Discussions between the World Bank and the government of Sierra Leone resulted in the decision to establish the Institute of Public Administration and Management as an institute of the University of Sierra Leone.
Funds were made available under the Second IDA Education Project for construction of suitable accommodation for the institute. The building on the site of the then Civil Service Training College was occupied in June 1980 and the institute started work in the 1980/81 academic year.
==Management==
The institute is managed by a dean of campus (formerly director) who reports directly to the vice-chancellor and principal of the University of Sierra Leone. A management team comprises the dean of campus, assistant dean of campus, deputy registrar and all heads of departments (administrative and academic).
==Functions==
The main functions of the institute include:
# Offering courses leading to the award of certificates, diplomas and degrees of the [[University of Sierra Leone]]; # Designing and organizing management training courses and programmes for personnel in the public and private sectors and NGOs; # Organising conferences, workshops and seminars; # General management, financial management and banking, human resource management, procurement and logistic, public policy, organisational effectiveness and capacity building, basic office skills, entrepreneurship, marketing management and information technology; # Providing advisory and consultancy services on aspects of management, finance and administration; # Carrying out studies, enquiries and research in its areas of competence either independently or in collaboration with interested parties; and # Conducting tests and other evaluation exercises for both the public and private sector organisations.
{{coord|8|29|6.41|N|13|13|54.09|W|}}
[[Category:Universities and colleges in Sierra Leone]] [[Category:Education in Freetown]] [[Category:1980s establishments in Sierra Leone]]
[[de:University of Sierra Leone]] [[ja:フォーラー・ベイ・カレッジ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox architect | name = Karen Burns | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1962 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | alma_mater = Monash University,
RMIT University | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | awards = | significant_buildings = | significant_projects = | significant_design = | website = }} '''Karen Burns''' (born 1962) is an architectural historian and theorist based in [[Melbourne]], Australia. She is currently a senior lecturer in architecture at the Melbourne School of Design, [[University of Melbourne]]. == Early years and education == Born in January 1962, Burns grew up in the Melbourne suburb of [[Beaumaris, Victoria|Beaumaris]]. Her feminist activism first found expression in 1978 when she worked as a volunteer at a newly established refuge for women and children escaping family violence. Burns studied English literature and art history at [[Monash University]], the latter with [[Patrick McCaughey]] and Conrad Hamann.{{Cite web|url = http://www.architecture.com.au/docs/vic-citations/conrad_hamann_citation.pdf?sfvrsn=2|title = Citation For Honorary Fellow – Conrad Hamann|date = |accessdate = 11 October 2015|website = |publisher = Royal Australian Institute of Architects|last = |first = }} She was Hamann’s first honours student. Burns graduated with a Bachelor of Arts (hons) in 1984 and a Master of Arts in 1987. She began studying architecture at [[RMIT University]] in 1986, and began editing the magazine ''Transition'' the same year. Her PhD, "Urban Tourism, 1851-53: sightseeing, representation and ''The Stones of Venice''" was completed in 1999 at the School of Fine Arts, Classical Studies and Archaeology, University of Melbourne.{{Cite web|url = https://minerva-access.unimelb.edu.au/handle/11343/36040|title = Urban tourism, 1851-53: sightseeing, representation and the Stones of Venice|date = 1999|accessdate = |website = Minerva access|publisher = University of Melbourne|last = Burns|first = Karen}} == Academic career == Burns has held academic positions at a number of universities in Melbourne. She began her academic career at RMIT University (1986–1995) and then joined the [[University of Melbourne Faculty of Arts|Department of English and Cultural Studies]] and Department of Fine Arts, Classics and Archaeology, University of Melbourne (1997–1999, 2001). She spent three years at the Centre for Ideas, [[University of Melbourne Faculty of VCA and MCM|Victorian College of the Arts]] (2002–2004), of which she was Acting Director in 2002–2003. She joined the new Department of Architecture at [[Monash University]] in 2008 and was later appointed as a Senior Lecturer in Architecture at the Melbourne School of Design, University of Melbourne, a position she still holds.{{Cite web|title = Lunchtime Art Forum - Dr Karen Burns (Monash University) Research in Architecture, Monash University|url = http://monash.edu/news/events/show/lunchtime-art-forum-dr-karen-burns-monash-university-research-in|website = monash.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}{{Cite web|title = DR KAREN BURNS - The University of Melbourne|url = http://www.findanexpert.unimelb.edu.au/display/person15488|website = www.findanexpert.unimelb.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}{{Cite web|title = Melbourne School of Design {{!}} University of Melbourne {{!}} Dr Karen Burns|url = https://msd.unimelb.edu.au/people/karen-burns|website = Melbourne School of Design|accessdate = 2015-10-11|first = Melbourne School of Design {{!}} University of|last = Melbourne}} Her academic research focuses on three principal areas: Australian frontier housing and problems of interpretation, late-twentieth-century feminist architectural history and theory, and alliances between architects, aesthetics and manufacturers in mid-nineteenth-century Britain. In relation to the last topic she is working on a book titled ''Object Lessons: Demonstrating Victorian Design Reform, 1835–1870.''{{Cite web|title = DR KAREN BURNS - The University of Melbourne|url = http://www.findanexpert.unimelb.edu.au/display/person15488#tab-overview|website = www.findanexpert.unimelb.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} Burns was an active researcher on the [[Australian Research Council]] funded project Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architectural Profession: women, work and leadership (2011-2014), which was led by [[Naomi Stead]] of the [[University of Queensland]].{{Cite web|title = Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: Women, Work, and Leadership - UQ Researchers|url = http://researchers.uq.edu.au/research-project/12113|website = researchers.uq.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} One of its key outcomes was [[Parlour: women, equity, architecture]]. Burns was instrumental in establishing this organisation with colleagues from the research project, and was responsible for coining the name Parlour.{{Cite web|title = Research - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/about/research/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} This can be understood in the context of her long engagement in feminist and social activism in architecture. Burns' has given invited keynote presentations at three conferences: ''Fabulations,'' the Annual Conference of [[SAHANZ]], [[University of Tasmania]], July 2012; ''Interstices'', University of Tasmania, November 2011; Whirlwinds Symposium, ''Sexuate Subjects: Politics, Poetics and Ethics'', [[The Bartlett|Bartlett School of Architecture]], [[University College London]], December 2010.{{Cite web|title = Confirmed Invited Speakers|url = https://www.ucl.ac.uk/sexuate-subjects/keynotespeakers|website = www.ucl.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}{{Cite web|title = 2011 Interstices Under Construction Symposium: Technics, Memory and the Architecture of History - Events|url = http://www.events.utas.edu.au/2011/november/2011-interstices-under-construction-symposium-technics,-memory-and-the-architecture-of-history|website = www.events.utas.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}{{Cite web|title = SAHANZ Conferences|url = http://www.sahanz.net/conferences/|website = www.sahanz.net|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}{{Cite web|title = Update: Technics, Memory and the Architecture of History|url = https://intersticesjournal.wordpress.com/2011/10/03/update-technics-memory-and-the-architecture-of-history/|website = Interstices: Journal of Architecture and Related Arts|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} She has presented her research work at many more conferences and symposia and is an active member of the academic community. == Editorial work and architectural criticism == Burns has played important roles in a range of publications, both scholarly and professional, as editor, contributor and advisor. === ''Transition: Discourse on Architecture'' === She was editor of ''[[Transition: Discourse on Architecture]]'', an influential quarterly journal published by RMIT University, from July 1986 – December 1991. This saw her edit 17 issues of the publication.{{Cite web|title = Transition (Collingwood, Vic.) - Details - Trove|url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/version/44725233|website = trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} From 1987, this was an editorial partnership with [[Harriet Edquist]].{{Cite journal|url = http://sahanz2015.be.unsw.edu.au/papers/Sawyer_Call-and-Response.pdf|title = Call-and-Response: Group Formation and Agency enacted through an Architectural Magazine, its Letters and Editorials|last = Sawyer|first = Mark|date = 2015|journal = Architecture Institutions and Change, Proceedings of SAHANZ |volume=32|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |isbn = 978 0 646 94298 8}}{{Cite web|title = Companion City {{!}} ACCA|url = https://www.accaonline.org.au/exhibition/companion-city|website = www.accaonline.org.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} Highlights of the journal over this period include: * no. 25 (1988) ''Women & Architecture'' * no. 26 (1988) ''The Bicentennial Issue'' * no. 27/28 (1989) ''New Urbanism'', which included a 25-page review of the New Parliament House by [[James Weirick]]. Transition was also a vehicle for exhibitions and competitions, including: * 1991 ''Transition Companion City Competition''. The competition "explored the future for our cities through ideas of design, energy conservation, planning and the environment" and also resulted in exhibition at [[Australian Centre for Contemporary Art]] (ACCA) curated by Burns and Edquist.{{Cite journal|url = https://www.accaonline.org.au/sites/default/files/1991_Transition%2C%20Companion%20City%20Forum%20review.pdf|title = Companion City Forum at the Australian Centre for Contemporary Art|last = London|first = Geoffrey|date = 1995|journal = Transition: Discourse on Architecture|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}{{Cite news|url = https://www.accaonline.org.au/sites/default/files/1991_30%20March_The%20Age%2C%20A%20wild%20ride%20for%20planning%20theory.pdf|title = A Wild Ride for Planning Theory|last = Stephens|first = John|date = 30 March 1991|work = The Age|access-date = 11 October 2015|via = }} * 1989 Transition 10th Anniversary Conference. This focussed on the topic ''[[Robin Boyd (architect)|Robin Boyd]]', the Architect as Critic'', and was accompanied by a tour of Boyd's houses and an exhibition (curated with [[Philip Goad]]) of Boyd's publications at the State Library of Victoria.{{Cite web|title = Robin Boyd : the architect as critic : an exhibition at the La Trobe Library of Victoria, 1989 / [editors: Karen Burns, Harriet Edquist]. - Version details - Trove|url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/version/209616773|website = trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} The conference papers were published together with Boyd's catalgoue raisonnee in 1992. === ''Australian & New Zealand Journal of Art'' === Burns edited four issues of this publication, which is the journal of the Art Association of Australia & New Zealand between 2004 and 2006.{{Cite web|title = journal - AAANZ {{!}} The Art Association of Australia and New Zealand|url = http://aaanz.info/journals/|website = AAANZ {{!}} The Art Association of Australia and New Zealand|accessdate = 2015-10-11|language = en-US}} === Editorial boards === Burns also sits on the editorial boards of a number of academic journals: ''Fabrications'' (journal of [[SAHANZ]]), ''[http://interstices.ac.nz/ Interstices]'', ''Ultima Thule'' and ''Architectural Theory Review.''.{{Cite web|title = FABRICATIONS latest issue|url = http://www.sahanz.net/publications/editors.html|website = www.sahanz.net|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} She has been a contributing editor to ''Architecture Australia''. === Criticism === Architectural criticism by Burns has been published in a range of professional journals including [[Architecture Australia]], Architectural Review Australia, Monument and Landscape Architecture Australia.{{Cite web|title = Dr Karen Burns|url = http://architectureau.com/contributors/Burns-Dr-Karen/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} == Activism and public engagement == Burns has a long history of involvement with feminist activism and social justice issues in architecture. She is a founding member of the Melbourne-based organisation E1027: Women in Architecture (1990) – established with [[Harriet Edquist]] and others.{{Cite book|title = E1027: from Modernist House to Feminist Collective|last = Burns|first = Karen|publisher = Cambridge Scholars Publishing|year = 2012|isbn = 978-1-4438-4027-9|location = Cambridge|pages = |editor-last = Edquist|editor-first = Harriet|chapter = |work = The Design Collective: An Approach to Practice|editor-link = Harriet Edquist|editor-last2 = Vaughan|editor-first2 = Laurene}} In 1991 the organisation had 80 members, including architects [[Maggie Edmond]], [[Anne Cunningham]], [[Ann Keddie]], Mary Ruth Sindrey, Val Austin, [[Suzanne Dance]], [[Eli Giannini]], Mardi Butcher, [[Jill Garner]] and Anna Ely. Members also included women artists such as Kathy Temin, Sarah Curtis, Lauren Berkowitz and Jan Nelson.{{Cite web|title = E1027 Women’s Architecture Collaborative - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/e1027/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-10-12|last = Burns|first = Karen|date = 2012}} In 1991 Burns curated the exhibition ''Insight Out'' with Anna Horne.{{Cite journal|url = |title = Insight/ Out. Exhibition at the 200 Gertrude Street Gallery, 3-25 July 1992|last = Hennessy|first = Peter|date = 1992|journal = Transition|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |last2 = Piccinini|first2 = Patricia|issue = 39|pages = 68–75}} This took the form of architectural installations at 200 Gertrude Street and five other outdoor sites in [[Fitzroy, Victoria|Fitzroy]], Melbourne. The exhibition examined urban change, gentrification, housing stress and historical memory. In 2013 Burns played a key role in establishing Parlour: women, equity, architecture, with [[Justine Clark]], [[Naomi Stead]] and others.{{Cite web|title = Welcome to Parlour - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/about/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-10-12}}{{Cite web|title = Interview: Justine Clark & Dr Karen Burns, Parlour {{!}} Australian Design Review|url = http://www.australiandesignreview.com/features/27445-interview-justine-clark-dr-karen-burns-parlour|website = www.australiandesignreview.com|accessdate = 2015-10-12|last = Tweeddale|first = Anna}} Developed as a "space to speak" for women in architecture, this provides research, resources and informed opinion about gender equity and architecture. Writing by Burns on Parlour includes: * Who Wants to be a Woman Architect?{{Cite web|title = Who wants to be a Woman Architect? - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/who-wants-to-be-a-woman-architect/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-10-12}} * The Elephant in our Parlour: Everyday Sexism in Architecture{{Cite web|title = The Elephant in our Parlour: everyday sexism in architecture - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/the-elephant-in-our-parlour-everyday-sexism-in-architecture/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}} * Why Do Women Leave?{{Cite web|title = Why do women leave? - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/why-do-women-leave/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}} Parlour also ran the 2012 symposium, Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture, which was co-convened by Burns with colleagues Justine Clark and Naomi Stead and hosted by the University of Melbourne.{{Cite web|title = Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/transform/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-10-12}}{{Cite web|title = Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/transform-altering-the-future-of-architecture-1/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-10-12|last = Kalms|first = Niki|publisher = Architecture Media|year = 2013}} == Selected publications == *Karen Burns, "[http://artinstitute.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0019/541900/3.1_BURNS,_Between_the_Walls.pdf Between the Walls: remembering colonial frontier space at Purrumbete, 1901 – 02]" in ''[http://artinstitute.unimelb.edu.au/publications/Interspaces Interspaces: Art + Architectural Exchanges from East to West]'', eds. Anthony White and Flavia Marcello (2012), pp. 1–15. *Karen Burns, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13264826.2012.730537#abstract "The Woman/Architect Distinction"], ''[http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/ratr20/17/2-3#.VhnswhOqqko Architectural Theory Review]'', vol.17, no. 2, December 2012, Taylor and Francis, Abingdon, Oxon, UK, pp 234–244. *Karen Burns, [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1531-314X.2011.01187.x/abstract "A Girl’s Own Adventure: gender in the contemporary architectural theory anthology"], ''[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1531-314X Journal of Architectural Education]'', vol. 65, no. 2, (2012) Wiley-Blackwell, New Jersey, 127–136. Also published on Parlour: women, equity, architecture http://archiparlour.org/a-girls-own-adventure/ *Karen Burns, [http://arrow.monash.edu.au/vital/access/manager/Repository/monash:73012 "Frontier conflict, contact, exchange: re-imagining colonial architecture"], Imagining... Proceedings of the 27th International SAHANZ Conference, 30 June to 2 July, [[SAHANZ|Society of Architectural Historians, Australia and New Zealand (SAHANZ)]], 2012, pp. 70–80. *Karen Burns, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13264826.2010.524706 "Ex libris: archaeologies of feminism, architecture and deconstruction"], [http://www.tandfonline.com/loi/ratr20#.VhnuNhOqqko Architectural Theory Review], vol 15, issue 3 (2010) Taylor & Francis, Oxon, UK, pp. 242–265. *Karen Burns, [http://arrow.monash.edu.au/hdl/1959.1/507961 "The Grammar of Ornament: A Pacific Tale"], Cultural Cross-Roads: Proceedings of the 26th International SAHANZ Conference, ed. Julia Gatley, Auckland University, Auckland 3–5 July 2009, [[SAHANZ|Society of Architectural Historians, Australia and New Zealand (SAHANZ)]]. *Karen Burns, "The Afterlife of an Architectural Event", ''[[Assemblage (journal)|Assemblage]]'', 41, [[MIT Press|The MIT Press]], Cambridge, Massachusetts, March 2001, 16. *Karen Burns, "A House For Josephine Baker", in [https://www.amazon.com/Postcolonial-Spaces-Wong-Chong-Thai/dp/1568980752 Postcolonial Space(s)], eds. Gülsüm Nalbantoglu and Bobby Wong Chong Thai, [[Princeton Architectural Press]], New York, 1997, 53–72. *Karen Burns, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3171405 "Topographies of Tourism: 'Documentary' Photography and The Stones of Venice",] [[Assemblage (journal)|Assemblage]] 32, [[MIT Press|The MIT Press]], Cambridge, Massachusetts, July 1997, 22–44. *Karen Burns, "Architecture/Discipline/Bondage" in [https://www.amazon.co.uk/Desiring-Practices-Architecture-Gender-Interdisciplinary/dp/0952177390 Desiring Practices: Architecture, Gender and the Interdisciplinary], eds. Duncan McCorquodale, Katerina Rüedi and Sarah Wigglesworth, [[Black Dog Publishing]], London, 1996, 72–87. == Exhibitions == Burns has curated a number of exhibitions. These include: *1991 ''Insight Out'', 200 Gertrude Street and 5 other outdoor sites in Fitzroy – with Anna Horne. *1991 ''Diologhi per una possibile Utopia'', Museo Civico Cuneo, Piedmont and Turin Politecnico, Italy – with [[Harriet Edquist]] and Mauro Baracco *1991 ''Companion City'', ACCA (Australian Centre of Contemporary Art) – with [[Harriet Edquist]]. *1989 ''Robin Boyd: The Architect as Critic'', [[State Library of Victoria]] – with [[Harriet Edquist]], [[Philip Goad]] and Dean Cass.{{Cite web|title = Robin Boyd : the architect as critic / an exhibition at the La Trobe Library, State Library of Victoria - Details - Trove|url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/18620069|website = trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-10-11}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{youtube|2DS4JQzG4FU |Ways to be Public}} (13 Jul 2015), London:[[Victoria and Albert Museum|V & A Museum]] * {{youtube|m4S0MB7tlFs |MAA Talking Homes Karen Burns}} (25 Oct 2011), Melbourne Architecture Annual * [http://rrrfm.libsyn.com/the-architects-show-242-victorian-architecture-awards Parlour: interview on "The Architects" RRR radio] (2012), Melbourne {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burns, Karen}} [[Category:Architectural historians]] [[Category:Australian women historians]] [[Category:Australian historians]] [[Category:Writers from Melbourne]] [[Category:University of Melbourne faculty]] [[Category:Monash University alumni]] [[Category:RMIT University alumni]] [[Category:Australian architecture writers]] [[Category:Australian women architects]] [[Category:Architectural theoreticians]] [[Category:Architecture educators]] [[Category:Australian feminists]] [[Category:Australian women academics]] [[Category:Architecture critics]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:University of Melbourne women]]

{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}
[[File:Kate Loder.jpg|thumb|Kate Loder, Lady Thompson]]
'''Kate Fanny Loder''', later '''Lady Thompson''', (21 August 1825 – 30 August 1904) was an English composer and pianist.<ref name="Grove_KL">{{cite encyclopedia | last=Temperley | first=Nicholas |editor1-last=Sadie |editor1-first=Stanley |editor2-last= | editor2-first= | encyclopedia=New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians |title=Kate (Fanny) Loder (b. Bath 21 August 1825 d. Headley, Surrey 30 August 1904)) |url= |edition= |year=2001 |publisher=Macmillan |volume=15 |location=London |id= |isbn=0-333-60800-3 |oclc= |page=59 |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
==Biography== Kate Loder was born on 21 August 1825,<ref name="Grove_KL"/> on Bathwick Street, [[Bathwick]],<ref name=rootsweb>{{cite web|title=Kate Fanny Loder|url=http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=haydencowan&id=I14727|publisher=Rootsweb|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> within [[Bath, Somerset]] where the Loder family were prominent musicians. Her father was the [[flautist]] [[George Loder (flautist)|George Loder]]. According to ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians|Grove]]'', her mother was a piano teacher born Fanny Philpot, who was the sister of the pianist [[Lucy Anderson]].<ref name="Grove_GL">{{cite encyclopedia | last=Temperley | first=Nicholas |editor1-last=Sadie |editor1-first=Stanley |editor2-last= | editor2-first= | encyclopedia=New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians |title=George Loder jr (b. Bath 1816 d. Adelaide 15 July 1868) |url= |edition= |year=2001 |publisher=Macmillan |volume=15 |location=London |id= |isbn=0-333-60800-3 |oclc= |page=58 |quote= |ref= }}</ref> Kate was also the sister of conductor and composer [[George Loder]],<ref name="Grove_KL"/> and the cousin of composer [[Edward Loder]].<ref name="GroveWomen">{{cite encyclopedia | last=Burton | first=Nigel |author2=Temperley, Nicholas |editor1-last=Sadie |editor1-first=Julie Anne |editor2-last=Samuel | editor2-first=Rhian |encyclopedia=New Grove Dictionary of Women Composers |title=Loder, Kate (Fanny) (b. Bath 21 August 1825 d. Headley, Surrey 30 August 1904) |url= |edition= |year=1994 |publisher=Macmillan |location=London |id= |isbn=0-333-51598-6 |oclc= |page=285 |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
However, genealogical research suggests Kate's mother was Frances Elizabeth Mary Kirkham (1802–50), daughter of Thomas Bulman Kirkham (1778–1845) and Marianne Beville Moore (c.1781 – 1810).<ref name=rootsweb/> Frances Kirkham's step-mother was Jane Harriett Philpot (1802–63), second wife to Thomas Bulman Kirkham and sister of the Lucy Philpot who married the violinist [[George Frederick Anderson]], becoming Lucy Anderson.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trees.ancestry.co.uk/tree/18927761/family?cfpid=734276569 |title=Lawleys of Bath Tree |publisher=Ancestry.co.uk |accessdate=13 June 2012}}</ref>
Kater Loder studied at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] in London. Her performance of [[Piano Concerto No. 1 (Mendelssohn)|Mendelssohn's G minor piano concerto]] at the Hanover-square Rooms on 27 May 1843, when she was aged 17, may have been her public debut.<ref>''The Morning Post'', Monday May 29, 1843</ref> The following year, in 1844, aged just 18, she became the first female professor of harmony at the Royal Academy.<ref>{{cite book |title=Symphonies|author=Smith, Alice Mary Smith|year=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The concise Oxford dictionary of opera|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WbDbuLJPKBgC&pg=PA295&lpg=PA295&dq=Kate+Loder+(1825%E2%80%931904)&source=bl&ots=5jPINfqzAT&sig=uSYzknM4G4i-z3lAT2TaUi5bP3Q&hl=en&ei=PxIlTcXEJcT38Abj5vnDAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Kate%20Loder%20(1825%E2%80%931904)&f=false|format=Digitized online by GoogleBooks|accessdate=5 January 2011|first= John Hamilton|last=Warrack|first2=Ewan|last2=West|year=1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IvoQQU1QL_QC&pg=PA286&dq=Kate+Loder+norton&hl=en&ei=pBAlTe3MFYKClAea3KCPAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Kate%20Loder%20norton&f=false|title=The Norton/Grove dictionary of women composers|format=Digitized online by GoogleBooks|first=Julie Anne|last=Sadie|first2=Rhian|last2=Samuel|year=1994|accessdate=5 January 2011}}</ref> On 16 December 1851 at [[St Marylebone Parish Church|St Marylebone Church]], Westminster, she married [[Sir Henry Thompson, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Thompson]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Henry Thompson|url=http://wc.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/igm.cgi?op=GET&db=haydencowan&id=I14729|publisher=Roots Web|accessdate=18 February 2012}}</ref> and soon afterwards, at her husband's insistence, gave up her public performing career. She remained active in music, continuing to compose, and taught pupils including [[Sarah Louisa Kilpack]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Musicians of Bath and Beyond: Edward Loder (1809-1865) and His Family|last=Temperley|first=Nicholas|page=186|isbn=9781783270781}}</ref> who nowadays is better known as an artist.
On 10 July 1871,<ref name="Musgrave">{{Cite book | last=Musgrave | first=Michael | title=Brahms 2: Biographical, Documentary, and Analytical Studies | publisher=Cambridge University Press | location=Cambridge | year=1987 | volume=2 | page=6 | isbn=0-521-32606-0 }}</ref> the first British performance of the ''[[A German Requiem (Brahms)|German Requiem]]'' of [[Johannes Brahms]] took place privately at Loder's home in [[Wimpole Street]], London. It was performed using a version for [[piano duet]] accompaniment which became known as the "London Version" ({{lang-de|Londoner Fassnung|links=no}}) of the Requiem.<ref>{{Cite journal |date=June 1997 |title=Brahms Ein deutsches Requiem, Op. 45 (London version). |journal=[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]] |page=92 |publisher=Haymarket |url=http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/June%201997/92/824216/47) |accessdate=30 January 2012 }}</ref> Brahms based it on an 1866 arrangement for piano of his first, six-movement version of the Requiem.<ref>{{Cite book | last=Swafford | first=Jan | title=Johannes Brahms: a Biography | publisher=Macmillan | location=London | year=1999 | page=311 | isbn=0-333-59662-5 }}</ref> The pianists were Kate Loder and [[Cipriani Potter]] (who was then 79 years old; he died that September).<ref name="Musgrave"/>
She died on 30 August 1904 at Headley Rectory,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://search.ancestry.co.uk/iexec?htx=View&r=5538&dbid=1904&iid=31874_222593-00318&fn=Kate+Fanny&ln=Thompson&st=d&ssrc=&pid=4879550 |title=England and Wales, National Probate Calendar |publisher=Ancestry.co.uk |accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref> [[Headley, Surrey]].<ref name="Grove_KL"/>
==Works== Selected works include:<ref name="GroveWomen"/><ref name="BritLib">{{cite encyclopedia |authorlink= |editor1-last=Ballchin |editor1-first=Robert |editor2-last= | editor2-first= | encyclopedia=Catalogue of Printed Music in the British Library to 1980 |title=Loder, afterwards Thompson (Kate Fanny), Lady |url= |edition= |year=1983 |publisher=K. G. Saur |volume=36 |location=London |id= |isbn=0-86291-333-0 |oclc= |page=87 |quote= |ref= }}</ref><ref name="Pandora">{{Cite book | last=Fuller | first=Sophie | title=Pandora Guide to Women Composers | publisher=Pandora | location=London | year=1994 | pages=191–192 | isbn=0-04-440897-8 }}</ref>
===Opera=== *''L'elisir d'amore'' (1855)
===Orchestral=== *Overture (1844)
===Chamber=== *String quartet in G minor (1846) *Sonata for violin and piano (1847) *String quartet in E minor (1847) *Piano trio (1886)
===Piano=== *Twelve studies (1852) *Three romances (1853) *''Pensée fugitive'' (1854) *''En Avant galop'' (1863) *Three Duets (1869) *Mazurka (1899) *Scherzo (1899)
===Songs=== *''My faint spirit'' (1854), text by [[Percy Bysshe Shelley|Shelley]]
==External links== *{{npg name|123623}}
==References==
===Sources=== * {{cite book |title=Musicians of Bath and Beyond: Edward Loder (1809-1865) and His Family |last= ed. Temperley |first= Nicholas |year= 2016 |publisher=The Boydell Press |isbn= 978 1 78327 078 1 |page= 314 |url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KfOjCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA40&dq=Musicians+of+Bath+and+Beyond&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjgyJGChO3LAhXDDxoKHd-_Ac8Q6AEIMDAA#v=onepage&q=Musicians%20of%20Bath%20and%20Beyond&f=false |accessdate=1 April 2016}}
===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Loder, Kate}} [[Category:1825 births]] [[Category:1904 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century classical composers]] [[Category:19th-century English people]] [[Category:20th-century classical composers]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:Female classical composers]] [[Category:English opera composers]] [[Category:English classical composers]] [[Category:English classical pianists]] [[Category:English women pianists]] [[Category:People from Bath, Somerset]] [[Category:Musicians from Somerset]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal Academy of Music]] [[Category:20th-century English musicians]] [[Category:19th-century classical pianists]] [[Category:19th-century English musicians]] [[Category:Female opera composers]] [[Category:20th-century women musicians]] [[Category:20th-century British composers]] [[Category:19th-century British composers]] [[Category:19th-century women musicians]]

revision.comment: Added Reinhardt University to list of universities in the US for its low-residency MFA in creative writing
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2016}} A '''low-residency program''' (or limited residency program) is a form of education, normally at the university level, which involves some amount of [[distance education]] and brief on-campus or specific-site residencies—residencies may be one weekend or several weeks. These programs are most frequently offered by colleges and universities that also teach standard full-time courses on campus. There are numerous [[Master's degree]] programs in a wide range of content areas; one of the most popular limited residency degree programs is the [[Master of Fine Arts]] in [[creative writing]]. The first such program was developed by [[Evalyn Bates]] and launched in 1963 at [[Goddard College]] in [[Plainfield, Vermont]].<ref name="Carlson, Scott">{{cite journal|last=Carlson|first=Scott|title=Goddard College Takes a Highly Unconventional Path to Survival|journal=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=Sep 9, 2011|volume=LVIII|pages=A6}}</ref>
There are low-residency MFA programs in creative writing, visual arts, photography, and painting. Other graduate programs that can earn a student a degree include Master of Arts, Master of Science, Master of Business Administration, and Master of Accounting. A few schools offer limited residency undergraduate options: [[Goddard College]], [[Prescott College]], [[Lesley University]], [[New Hampshire Institute of Art]], and [[Union Institute & University]].
== Structure == Programs vary, but an intensive, low-residency model requires students to come to campus every six months for 1-2 weeks, during which time students engage in a variety of activities and lectures during the day, and create detailed study plans. During the non-residency semester periods, students study independently, sending in "packets" to their faculty mentors every month or so. The content of the packets varies with each individual, but focuses on research, writing, and reflection related to each student's individualized study plan. A few schools, such as Western State Colorado University, actually conduct live online classes via Skype each week during the non-residency periods as well as having instructors reading students' work and provide written feedback weekly.
==List of colleges with low-residency programs==
===United States=== * [[Antioch University Los Angeles]], MFA in Creative Writing * [[Antioch University]], [http://www.antioch.edu/phd/ Ph.D. in Leadership and Change] * [[Arcadia University]], MFA in Creative Writing * [[Ashland University]] **MFA Poetry **MFA Creative Nonfiction **MFA Fiction **MFA Interdisciplinary * [[Augsburg University]], [http://www.augsburg.edu/mfa/ MFA in Creative Writing] * [[Bastyr University]] [http://www.bastyr.edu/academics/areas-study/midwifery-degree-programs MS in Midwifery] * [[Bennington College]] **MFA in Writing **MA in Teaching a Second Language (MATSL) * [[Boston Architectural College]] ** [http://the-bac.edu/education-programs/school-of-architecture/master-of-architecture/march-distance Master of Architecture, DIstance] ** [http://the-bac.edu/education-programs/school-of-design-studies/master-of-design-studies/distance-online-masters-sustainable-design Master of Architecture, Sustainable Design] ** [http://the-bac.edu/education-programs/school-of-design-studies/master-of-design-studies/distance-online-masters-historic-preservation Master of Design Studies, Historic Preservation] ** [http://the-bac.edu/education-programs/school-of-design-studies/master-of-design-studies/mds-design-for-human-health Master of Design Studies, Design for Human Health] * [[Burlington College]], [https://www.burlington.edu/content/distance-learning Independent Degree Program] * [[California College of the Arts]], [https://www.cca.edu/academics/graduate/comics MFA in Comics] * [[Carlow University]], [http://gradstudies.carlow.edu/creative/index.html MFA in Creative writing] * [[Chatham University]], [http://www.chatham.edu/ccps/mfa.cfm MFA creative writing] * [[College of Saint Elizabeth]] (Morristown, New Jersey), [http://www.cse.edu/academics/graduate-programs/ M.A. in Theology] * [[Converse College]] (Spartanburg, South Carolina) [http://www.converse.edu/mfa MFA in Creative Writing] * [[Drew University]] (Madison, New Jersey), [http://www.drew.edu/graduate/academics/poetry-mfa MFA in Poetry] * [[Eastern Kentucky University]] (Richmond, Kentucky) revision.text:
'''Luigi Sturzo Institute''' was founded in 1951 by [[Luigi Sturzo]] <ref>cfr. G. De Rosa, L. Sturzo, in Dizionario storico del movimento cattolico italiano. 1860-1980, dir. da F. Traniello e G. Campanini, vol. II (I protagonisti), Casale Monferrato, Marietti, 1982, pp. 614-24. D'obbligo è poi la segnalazione dell'ormai classico lavoro di G. De Rosa Sturzo, Torino, Utet, 1977 (con ampi riferimenti bibliografici alle pp. 483-505).</ref> of the Partito Popolare (Italian [[Italian People's Party (1919)|Popular Party]]). The mission of The Luigi Sturzo Institute <ref>http://www.sturzo.it</ref> is to endorse research in the historical sciences, [[sociology]], political and economical fields by providing vast documentation in the archive library, facilitate canvassers, issue publications and maintain various alliances with other national and international institutes.
Located in [[Palazzo Baldassini]], the institute’s remarkable building was constructed by architect [[Antonio da Sangallo the Younger|Antonio da Sangallo il Giovane]]<ref>Tafuri, Manfredo. Ricerca del Rinascimento. Roma: 1992.</ref> in 1515. The interior walls are decorated with [[fresco]]s from various artists including several who attended La Scuola di Raffaelo.
Within the edifice, the institute organizes and preserves archives containing documentation specified around the validation of the [[Roman Catholic]] Movement. In the library, other documentation is assembled, more specifically around the [[social science]]s as well as modern and contemporary [[history]].
Ongoing research in the institute extends to the fields of [[psychology]], [[politics]], history, [[jurisprudence]] and [[economics]]. The conducted research is integrated with seminars organized by the institute to share the new information and provide information in areas of interest.
The formation sector provides courses for graduates that teach the work specifics of several jobs in the cultural organization career based on the common [[Europe]]an model.
The diffusion and verifications of scientific results are dispersed predominantly by our publications, one of which is our journal, ''Sociologia'',<ref>[http://www.sturzo.it/newsite/pubblica/pub_riv.htm Fondazione Sturzo<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325222040/http://www.sturzo.it/newsite/pubblica/pub_riv.htm |date=2008-03-25 }}</ref> published every four months, which discusses historical and social sciences.
The institute develops numerous of its activities in collaboration with other national and international institutes.
== References ==
<references />

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Mahinder Watsa | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Mahinder C. Watsa | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|90|2014|7|21}} | birth_place = [[Punjab]]<ref name=sexguru/> | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = [[India]]n | other_names = | occupation = [[Sexologist]], [[sex columnist]] and [[sex educator]] | known_for = | spouse = Promila (deceased 2006)<ref name=sexguru/> }} '''Mahinder Watsa''' is an [[India]]n [[sexologist]] who is well known for his [[sex column]]s in newspapers and magazines and his contributions to promote [[sex education]] in India.<ref name=sexguru>{{cite news|title=Ask the Sexpert: The 90-year-old sex guru|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-28353027|accessdate=21 July 2014|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=sexpert>{{cite news|author1=Lhendup G. Bhutia|title=An Appointment with the Sexpert|url=http://www.openthemagazine.com/article/living/an-appointment-with-the-sexpert|accessdate=21 July 2014|work=[[OPEN (magazine)|OPEN]]}}</ref>
==Life and work== Mahinder Watsa's father was a [[military physician]]. Watsa is [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]]. When he was around 7 years old, his family spent some time in [[Rangoon]].<ref name=sexguru/>
During his time at a medical college in Mumbai, Watsa stayed with friends of his family. Through them, he met his future wife, Promila. Despite coming from different backgrounds and castes (he is [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]], she was originally from [[Sindh]]), and going against a tradition of arranged marriages, the two wed after being friends for a number of years. The couple had a son and lived for a while in the 1950s in the [[United Kingdom]], during which time Watsa worked as a hospital [[residency (medicine)|houseman]] and [[Specialist registrar|registrar]]. The family returned to India after his father fell ill and Watsa found work in for [[Glaxo]] as a medical officer, while simultaneously running a private practice as a [[gynecologist]] and [[obstetrician]].<ref name=sexguru/>
Watsa began a career as a columnist in the 1960s when, in his late 30s, he was asked to start writing a medical advice column for a women's magazine. He continued authoring health columns for several women's magazines, such as [[Femina (India)|Femina]], Flair, and Trend, into the 1970s until he encountered resistance from an editor who insisted upon censoring queries about sexual health. Watsa however maintained his writing through numerous alternative outlets including [[List of men's magazines|men's magazines]] (such as 'Fantasy') and, later, websites.<ref name=sexguru/><ref name=sexpert/><ref name=sex@90>{{cite news|last1=Pawar|first1=Yogesh|title=Mahinder Watsa: Talking sex @ 90|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-mahinder-watsa-talking-sex-90-1997076|accessdate=21 July 2014|work=[[DNA India]]|date=22 June 2014}}</ref>
One of the readers of the Femina column had filed an obscenity lawsuit claiming that the publishers were fabricating the letters to increase readership. The editor, Sathya Saran, managed to convince the judge to drop the case by delivering a sack of unopened letters to him.<ref name=ellen_barry/>
Through his work as a columnist he became aware of the lack of [[sex education]] in India. In 1974, while working as a consultant for the [[Family Planning Association of India]] (FPAI), Watsa proposed that a sexual counselling and education program should be introduced. Despite oppositions, FPAI accepted his advice and started India's first sex education, counselling and therapy centre. In 1976, he organised India's first workshop on [[human sexuality]] and family life. The workshop was also addressed by [[Ashok Row Kavi]], a notable [[LGBT rights]] activist in India. In the early 1980s, Watsa left his practice to work full-time in counselling and education.<ref name=sexguru/>
===''Ask the Sexpert'' column=== In 2005, aged 80, Watsa began writing a column called ''Ask the Sexpert'' for the newspaper [[Mumbai Mirror]], which is noted for its witty replies to queries.<ref name=sexguru/> The newspaper has subsequently been threatened with lawsuits and accusations of obscenity.<ref name=sexguru/><ref name=ignorance>{{cite news|author1=Sean McLain|title=India’s Sex Guru: The Problem is Ignorance|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/11/25/the-problems-indias-sex-guru-faces/|accessdate=21 July 2014|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=25 November 2013}}</ref> Suchitra Dalvie, a gynaecologist, conducted a study by analysing more than 500 letters sent to the column. According to her, the study revealed a lack of sex education even among urban and relatively well-educated Indians.<ref name=sexguru/> In August 2014, his editor estimated that he has received more 40,000 queries for the column.<ref name=ellen_barry>{{cite news|last1=Barry|first1=Ellen|title=90-Year-Old Sex Columnist Shatters Taboos in India|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/09/world/asia/mahinder-watsa-offers-sex-advice-to-indians.html|accessdate=10 November 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 August 2014}}</ref>
==Awards== * ''2014 Dr. Ved Vyas Puri Award'': On 17 June 2014, he was given this award by the [[Family Planning Association of India]] (FPAI) for his contributions to sex education in India.<ref name=sex@90/><ref>{{cite news|title=Bees, Birds, and Bananas|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/columns/mumbai-001/Bees-Birds-and-Bananas/articleshow/36728877.cms|accessdate=21 July 2014|work=[[Mumbai Mirror]]|date=18 June 2014}}</ref>
==Published papers== *{{cite journal|last1=Watsa|first1=Mahinder C|title=Premarital sexual behaviour of urban educated youth in India|journal=Workshop on Sexual Aspects of AIDS/STD Prevention in India|date=1993|publisher=[[Tata Institute of Social Sciences]]|location=[[Bombay]]}} *{{cite journal|last1=Watsa|first1=M. C.|title=Sexual Health Services for Young People|journal=Journal of Family Welfare|url=http://medind.nic.in/jah/t04/s1/jaht04s1p36g.pdf|date=2005|volume=50|issue=I|page=36|publisher=[[Family Planning Association of India]]}} *{{cite journal|author1=M. C. Watsa|author2=Amita Dhanu|title=Three decades of meeting sexual and reproductive health needs of young people.|url=http://medind.nic.in/jah/t04/s1/jaht04s1p83g.pdf|journal=Journal of Family Welfare|date=2013|volume=50|pages=83–88}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite news|title=Ask the Sexpert: The 90-year-old sex guru|author=Vibeke Venema|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-28353027|work=[[BBC News]]|date=21 July 2014}} * {{cite news|title=What the sex doctor orders|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/what-the-sex-doctor-orders-20130227-2f64a.html|author= Amrit Dhillon|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=28 February 2013}} * {{cite news|last1=Wasta|first1=Mahinder|title=Ask the Sexpert (Archives)|url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/columns/ask-the-sexpert|work=[[Mumbai Mirror]]}} * {{cite news|last1=Barry|first1=Ellen|title=90-Year-Old Sex Columnist Shatters Taboos in India|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/09/world/asia/mahinder-watsa-offers-sex-advice-to-indians.html|date=8 August 2014|work=[[The New York Times]]}} * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6659414/ ''Ask the Sexpert'' (2017)] - [[IMDb]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Watsa, Mahinder}} [[Category:Indian sexologists]] [[Category:Sex educators]] [[Category:Sex columnists]] [[Category:Indian gynaecologists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian medical doctors]] [[Category:Medical doctors from Punjab, India]]

'''Markos Mamalakis''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Μάρκος Μαμαλάκης; born October 30, 1932) is a [[Greek people|Greek]] [[economist]] specialising in [[Economic development|development]] economics, particularly in [[Latin America]].
Born in [[Salonika]], he graduated from the Experimental High School of the [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]] in 1950, then attended the Law School of the University and received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in Law, with the distinction ''[[summa cum laude]]'' in 1955. He did graduate work at [[Ludwig Maximilians University of Munich]] from 1955 to 1957, and [[University of California, Berkeley]] from 1957 to 1962, where he received his [[Master's degree|M.A.]] (1959), and [[Ph.D.]] (1962) with a dissertation entitled ''Inflation and Growth: An Asset Preference Analysis. With a Case Study of the Chilean Inflation''. He has taught or been a visiting scholar at the University of California, Berkeley; [[University of Western Ontario]]; [[Universidad de Chile]]; [[Yale]]; [[University of Göttingen]]; [[Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars]]; [[Inter-American Development Bank]]; and the [[University of Giessen]].
He is a professor of economics at the [[University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee]].
He was one of the first to argue that there is no "[[wikt:magic bullet|magic bullet]]" to development, but that development solutions must take into account the effects and circumstances of the location. He has published widely on [[macroeconomics]] in developing economies and welfare and sector effects. He argued for the fruitfulness of a [[mesoeconomics|mesoeconomic]] analysis of social interactions, rather than a strictly microeconomic or macroecomic approach.
Markos is a father of twelve and grandfather of thirty-seven. He and his wife celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary on January 31, 2010.
==External links== * [http://www.uwm.edu/~mamalaki/ Dr. Mamalakis's faculty home page at University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee] * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011045733/http://www.uwm.edu/News/report/old/april99/people.html |date=October 11, 2007 |title=Markos Mamalakis: The man behind 'mesoeconomics' }}
{{Authority control}}
