revision.text:
[[File:Sigfrid Gauch.jpg|thumb|Sigfrid Gauch in 2008]] '''Sigfrid Gauch''' (born 9 March 1945) is a German writer. He lives in Mainz.
Gauch is the son of [[Hermann Gauch]], a [[Nazi Party|Nazi]] official and member of the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]. He was born in [[Offenbach-Hundheim]] in the last few weeks of the [[Second World War]]. His parents separated when he was a young boy.<ref name = "cop">Copley, Antony, "Hitler's Children, A Preface to Sigfid Gauch's Vaterspuren", in Gauch, Sigfrid, ''Traces of My Father'', trans. [[William Radice]], Northwestern University Press, xi-xx.</ref> He studied at the Universities of [[Heidelberg University|Heidelberg]] and [[University of Mainz|Mainz]].
He worked as a school teacher, teaching German, philosophy and ethics at the ''Integrierte Gesamtschule'' in [[Mainz]]. He was awarded a doctorate from the University of Mainz in 1985 for a dissertation on "Overt and covert spellings in literary [[Jacobinism]]". It was later published as ''Friedrich Joseph Emerich – ein deutscher Jakobiner. Studien zu Leben und Werk''.
In the 1970s Gauch published essays and poetry. He made his name with his book ''Vaterspuren'' (Traces of My Father) in 1979, an influential memoir that began what later became a genre of literature about children of Nazi parents attempting to come to terms with their family's past.<ref>Figge, Susan, "Father books: Memoirs of the Children of Fascist Fathers", ''Revealing Lives'', Yallom and Bell, eds, pp 196-200.</ref> He later published ''Fundsachen. Die Quellen zum Roman Vaterspuren'', a collection of primary source material related to the book. His novels ''Winterhafen'' (2010) and ''Schattenbilder'' (2012) explore the same issues through fiction.<ref name = "cop"/>
In addition to his novels, short stories and poetry collections Gauch has co-edited numerous anthologies, especially with regard to literature from [[Rhineland-Palatinate]], including, from 1994, the ''Rheinland-pfälzisches Jahrbuch für Literatur'' (Rhineland-Palatinate Yearbook of literature) published by Brandes & Apsel. Since 2002 this has come out under the title ''Jahrbuch für Literatur'' (Yearbook for Literature). Since 2004 he has edited the Edition Schrittmacher series of books, of which 30 volumes have been published.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gauch, Sigfrid}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:People from Rhineland-Palatinate]] [[Category:Philosophy teachers]] [[Category:German ethicists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:German male writers]]

{{Unreferenced|date=February 2007}} {{Infobox video game |title = SimPark |image = SimPark Coverart.jpg |developer = [[Maxis]] |publisher = [[Maxis|Maxis Kids]] |designer = Roxana Wolosenko
Claire Curtin |programmer = Ed Nanale |artist = Bonnie Borucki
Sharon Barr |composer = [[Jerry Martin (composer)|Jerry Martin]] |engine = |series = ''[[List of Sim video games|Sim]]'' |released = [[1996 in video gaming|1996]] |genre = [[Simulation video game|Simulation]], [[Educational game|Education]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Windows 3.1x|Windows 3.x]], [[Mac OS]] }} '''''SimPark''''' is a 1996 [[video game]] by [[Maxis]]. The object of the game is to cultivate and manage a successful [[park]]. Similar to ''[[SimTown]]'', it is targeted more towards [[child]]ren than the average player. ''SimPark'' attempts to show the importance of [[ecology|ecological]] balance. It could well be considered a 'lite' version of ''[[SimIsle: Missions in the Rainforest|SimIsle]]''. == Gameplay == [[Image:Simpark.jpeg|thumb|left|''SimPark'' screenshot]] Players have to quickly learn how doing (or not doing) various things will affect how their park grows. For instance, if certain [[flower]] types aren't planted, the park won't attract [[bee]]s. If the bees aren't flying around the park, then [[pollination]] won't occur, which is an important aspect of keeping the park growing. On top of properly managing the [[plant]] and [[animal]] population, players are also required to identify the park's plants and animals. Players often receive in-game email, such as their boss telling them to make the park more diverse, or their virtual mother telling about life back at home (e.g.: "I baked you a cake..." etc.) Occasionally, the Boss's pet frog Rizzo will make an appearance on the screen to give the player advice, or nag about the way they're handling things. The park can experience disasters, including: *[[Waste|Garbage]] Dump: The Garbage Dump is just a big pile of rubbish. As soon as it is made, rats start to produce from it and inhabit your park. The only way to get rid of the garbage dump is to put water on it or place lots of garbage-eating animals such as rats and black bears, around the garbage dump. *[[Fire]] * [[Kudzu]] * [[Alien invasion]]: The Alien Invasion consists of flat, pink-and-blue creatures that litter the park grounds and sometimes float on the water. If the map is clicked to get a zoomed-out map view, the pattern the Aliens form may be in the shape of letters. One example of this is a message which reads: "Surrender, Dorothy". This is a parody of the movie ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''. The only way to get rid of aliens, aside from using cheat codes, is to bulldoze them with the "[[Bulldozer]]" tool. The option of using a microphone feature allows you to click on park-goers and listen to what they have to say. Some of the more memorable quotes include, "My socks don't match," "I didn't brush my teeth this morning," "Eddie! Oh Eddie! Where are you?" and "My favourite book is ''Wind in the Willows." ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/simpark}} {{Sim series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Simpark}} [[Category:1996 video games]] [[Category:Maxis Sim games]] [[Category:Children's educational video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Mac OS games]] [[Category:Strategy video games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Video games with isometric graphics]] [[Category:Video games set in North America]]

{{Korean name|[[Song (Korean name)|Song]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Song Yoo Geun
{{linktext|송|유|근}} | image = (명량 회오리 바다를 향하여) 추천 릴레이 영상 송유근.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|11|27}} | birth_place = [[Guri]], [[Gyeonggi Province]]
[[South Korea]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[South Korea]]n | other_names = | education = [[Korean University of Science and Technology]] (UST; [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D. candidate]])
[[Inha University]] (dropped outAchieved [[Bachelor's degree]] using [http://www.cb.or.kr/creditbank/info/info7_1.do Credit Bank System]. {{cite web |author=미디어다음 |title=`천재소년' 송유근 학점은행으로 학사모 | URL = http://media.daum.net/breakingnews/view.html?cateid=1067&newsid=20090223162417627&p=yonhap |accessdate=2015-12-22}}) | alma_mater = | known_for = The youngest [[South Korea]]n [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D. candidate]] | occupation = | footnotes = }} '''Song Yoo-geun''' (born November 27, 1997) is a [[South Korea]]n ex-[[graduate school]] student, who has been enrolled in the [[Korean University of Science and Technology]] (UST) from 2008 to 2017. He is broadly known as 'Genius Boy' in South Korea since 2004. In October 2015, his first paper, written with his advisor, Dr. [[Park Seok-jae]], entitled "Axisymmetric, Nonstationary Black Hole Magnetospheres: Revisited"{{cite journal|title = AXISYMMETRIC, NONSTATIONARY BLACK HOLE MAGNETOSPHERES: REVISITED|url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-637X/812/1/8|journal = The Astrophysical Journal|volume = 812|issue = 1|doi = 10.1088/0004-637x/812/1/8|first = Yoo Geun|last = Song|first2 = Seok Jae|last2 = Park}} appeared in the ''[[Astrophysical Journal]]'' (ApJ). As UST requires one published paper in a journal listed in the [[Science Citation Index]] as a graduation requirement, this article, along with his Ph.D. defense titled "Astrophysical Applications of General Relativity"{{cite web|title = 천재소년 송유근, 내년 2월 최연소 박사 된다|url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2015/11/18/0200000000AKR20151118066700063.HTML|website = 연합뉴스|accessdate = 2015-12-08|language = ko-KR}} qualified him to apply for a Ph.D. degree to be conferred in February 2016. This would have made him the youngest-ever Korean to earn a Ph.D. degree. However, the paper was soon retracted due to plagiarizing a 2002 book chapter.{{cite web |author=The Astrophysical Journal |title=Astrophysical Journal Paper Retracted for Plagiarism | URL = http://aas.org/posts/news/2015/11/astrophysical-journal-paper-retracted-plagiarism |accessdate=2015-11-28}}{{cite web |author=Retraction Watch |title=Black hole paper by teenaged prodigy retracted for duplication | URL = http://retractionwatch.com/2015/11/25/black-hole-paper-by-teenaged-prodigy-retracted-for-duplication |accessdate=2015-11-28}} == Life before October 2015 == Song Yoo-geun left a prodigy school he attended in 2003. Six months of his independent study enabled him to solve pre-calculus problems. In August 2004, at age 6, he passed [http://www.q-net.or.kr/crf005.do?id=crf00503&jmCd=6921 "Craftsman Information Processing" (정보처리기능사)] certification examination. In November of the same year, his parents tried to enroll him at a local elementary school (Shim Seok Elementary School; 심석초등학교) as a sixth grader. While Song did not perform well, obtaining a score of 12% on his math exam, his parents maintained that Song was neither used to, or interested in, calculating equations that lacked meaning.{{cite web|title="공부에 빠진 유근이 배울 곳이 없었다" : 주간동아|url = http://weekly.donga.com/List/3/all/11/77317/1|website = weekly.donga.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}} Although the school allowed this at first, it later reversed its decision, citing administrative difficulties. Song's parents took the elementary school to court, where the court ruled that the school's decision was unlawful in April 2005, allowing Song to study there as a sixth grader.{{cite web|title = 진학시기 놓친 '일곱살 영재'|url = http://www.hankyung.com/news/app/newsview.php?aid=2005041896698&sid=01062004&nid=910|website = www.hankyung.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} As Korean students must enroll in middle school within 30 days of the beginning of the school year, Song could not enroll in middle school even after winning the lawsuit. Song's parents decided to opt for a Korean equivalent of the [[General Educational Development|GED]]. Song passed the test, which gave him the right to enroll in high school in May 2005. He then went on to pass the test that certified him as a high school graduate in August 2005. Thus, Song finished the twelve-year curriculum spanning elementary school – middle school – high school in nine months, setting a new record.{{cite web|title = 9세 대학생? 8세 신동 송유근군 고졸검정고시 합격 : 뉴스 : 동아닷컴|url = http://news.donga.com/3/all/20050825/8222190/1|website = news.donga.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} In October 2005, he applied and was accepted to [[Inha University]] through its early decision plans, which allows exceptional students to bypass the Korean equivalent of [[SAT]]s at age 7, being the youngest [[university]] student ever. During his interview with [[Inha University]], Song demonstrated his understanding of the [[Schrödinger equation]], a [[partial differential equation]] which is of central importance to [[quantum mechanics]] theory. Considering his young age, Inha University formed a committee of seven, named "Song Yoo-Geun Committee," including professors and his mother, who gave him private lessons instead of the usual classroom style lectures.{{cite web|title = ‘천재소년’ 인하대 송유근군의 최근 생활은？ – Sciencetimes|url = http://www.sciencetimes.co.kr/?news=%25EC%25B2%259C%25EC%259E%25AC%25EC%2586%258C%25EB%2585%2584-%25EC%259D%25B8%25ED%2595%2598%25EB%258C%2580-%25EC%2586%25A1%25EC%259C%25A0%25EA%25B7%25BC%25EA%25B5%25B0%25EC%259D%2598-%25EC%25B5%259C%25EA%25B7%25BC-%25EC%2583%259D%25ED%2599%259C%25EC%259D%2580%25EF%25BC%259F|website = www.sciencetimes.co.kr|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} Inha University also provided Song with his own lab, and a residence space, so that he can stay with his parents, at his parents' request. His first semester [[GPA]] was 3.8/4.5,{{cite web|title = 천재소년 송유근 1학기 성적 3.8 - 조선닷컴 인물|url = http://www.chosun.com/national/news/200608/200608220162.html|website = www.chosun.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} approximately equivalent to a B+.{{cite web|title = ‘천재소년’ 송유근, 8살때 대학 입학 첫 학기 학점이 ‘B+’...못말리는 천재성|url = http://sports.khan.co.kr/news/sk_index.html?art_id=201511181737543&sec_id=540201|website = sports.khan.co.kr|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} However, In December 2008, mere two years after he has begun his studies, he decided to withdraw from Inha University, since he felt "difficult to study within the framework that the professor has arbitrarily decided for themselves." He said, "I want to study string theory or big bang theory, but I cannot do that as an undergraduate student."Of the 140 credits required for graduation, Song received 53 credits from Inha University, and 113 credits from an on-line degree institution. On this, Inha University said, that it "respects Song's decisions.{{cite web|title = 인하대, 송유근군 대학원 진학 결정 존중|url = http://news.sbs.co.kr/news/endPage.do?news_id=N1000516016|website = SBS NEWS|accessdate = 2015-12-06|language = ko-KR}}" To fulfill total credit hours to apply for a graduate school, he achieved [[Bachelor's degree]] using [http://www.cb.or.kr/creditbank/info/info7_1.do Credit Bank System].{{cite web |author=미디어다음 |title=`천재소년' 송유근 학점은행으로 학사모 | URL = http://media.daum.net/breakingnews/view.html?cateid=1067&newsid=20090223162417627&p=yonhap |accessdate=2015-12-22}} [[Korea University of Science and Technology|University of Science & Technology]] (UST) as a master's student{{cite web|title = '천재소년' 송유근 UST 석사과정 입학|url = http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2009/02/25/2009022501597.html|website = news.chosun.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} in February 2009, with the intention of studying astronomy. Like Inha University, UST formed a committee of professors, titled "Song Yoo-Geun Project," and Song was given private lessons in lieu of classroom lectures.{{cite web|title = ‘13세’ 송유근 군 UST 석박사 통합과정 합격 {{!}} 동아사이언스|url = http://www.dongascience.com/news/view/-387254/bef|website = dongascience.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} The topics of the lectures varied from [[quantum field theory]], [[nuclear physics]], [[astronomy]], and [[topology]]. The university set aside 100 million Korean won (approximately $80,000 USD) for Song's classes and research. In February 2010, UST announced that Song was accepted to its combined master's and Ph.D. program, with the goal of obtaining a Ph.D. in 2012. He studied under the guidance of Dr. [[Park Seok-jae]], whose specialized area is [[black hole]] modeling. He passed his candidacy exam in November 2014, by a presentation entitled "Gromov-Witten Invariants on Real Hypersurfaces of Kähler Manifold,{{cite web|title = '수학자로 진로 정해' '천재소년' 송유근 근황 - 케이신문 K신문|url = http://search.ksinmun.com/view/y/2014-11-21/51663.html|website = search.ksinmun.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208110244/http://search.ksinmun.com/view/y/2014-11-21/51663.html|archivedate = 2015-12-08|df = }}" and declared his intention to become a mathematician to the press. However, he again changed his mind to study [[black hole]].{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} == Controversy == === Air Purification System Controversy === During a press conference in 2005, after he was admitted to Inha University, he brought a machine that purifies air, and gave a demonstration of it. The press and the Inha University officials reported that Song claimed it to be a machine that he invented himself, to thank the Korean citizens for their support, it became known later that the machine was in fact designed by a small company.{{cite web|title = 송유근군이 발명했다던 '공기 정화기' 알고보니 중소기업 제품|url = http://news.joins.com/article/1710137|website = news.joins.com|accessdate = 2015-12-06}} According to CEO of JC Technologies, Song's father told him that being able to show off the machine in front of the press will help with its sales, and he had borrowed it from the company. Song's father quickly admitted this misunderstanding, saying that "Song has ambitions to study air purification methods using photosynthesis, so he just did a demonstration. There may have been parts where we were misunderstood, as this was our first large-scale press conference." === Plagiarism Controversy === In 2015, ''[[The Astrophysical Journal]]'' (ApJ) retracted Song's paper due to plagiarism issue. ApJ noticed that the paper plagiarized a 2002 book chapter, which was originally a proceeding paper of Song's advisor, Dr. [[Park Seok-jae]]. {{Quote|text=Song & Park (2015) draws extensively from an earlier publication by Dr. Park, "Stationary Versus Nonstationary Force-Free Black Hole Magnetospheres," in Black Hole Astrophysics 2002: Proceedings of the Sixth APCTP Winter School (World Scientific Publishing Co., 2002). In fact, the differences are modest, mostly confined to an alternate formulation of the analytic results, and could raise the question of copyright violation. Park (2002) is not part of the peer-reviewed literature, and scientists frequently use a conference proceeding as the rough draft of a subsequent submission to a professional peer-reviewed journal. However, in this case the overlap between the 2002 book chapter and 2015 paper is exceptionally large. |author=The American Astronomical Society |source=[https://aas.org/posts/news/2015/11/astrophysical-journal-paper-retracted-plagiarism Astrophysical Journal Paper Retracted for Plagiarism] }} {{Quote|text="This article by Yoo Geun Song & Seok Jae Park has been retracted at the request of the Editor-in-Chief due to an unacceptably large overlap with "Stationary Versus Nonstationary Force-Free Black Hole Magnetospheres," published in Black Hole Astrophysics 2002: Proceedings of the Sixth APCTP Winter School (World Scientific Publishing Co., 2002). Please see https://aas.org/posts/news/2015/11/astrophysical-journal-paper-retracted-plagiarism for a more complete explanation." |author=Astrophysical Journal |source=[http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0004-637X/815/1/79 RETRACTION: "AXISYMMETRIC, NONSTATIONARY BLACK HOLE MAGNETOSPHERES: REVISITED"] }} Dr. Park first denied the plagiarism controversy towards Song, insisting he will "resign his position if any part of his paper is found unoriginal."[http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2015/11/20/0200000000AKR20151120109500063.HTML] He also argued that Song's work on partial differential equation is totally of Song's, which is worth to be a "meaningful contribution as a doctoral student." Against the argument that several parts of Song's paper is appeared to overlap Dr. Park's proceeding in 2002, Dr. Park said that the proceeding is conventionally not considered as an 'official' paper, so citing the proceeding paper is not a requirement nor an offence against academic integrity or research ethics{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}. In November, UST finally decided to take a disciplinary action to Song, punishing him for an offence.{{cite web |author=ZDNet Korea |title=UST "송유근, 표절 유감…학칙에 따라 징계 진행" |URL= http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=001&oid=092&aid=0002087075 |accessdate=2015-12-22}} In August 2018, UST officially announced that Song was disqualified in the final defense and he failed to have the Ph.D. degree. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{cite news |title=Eight-year-old physics genius enters university |newspaper=Korea Herald |date=November 5, 2005 |author=Hwang Si-young |url=http://www.koreaherald.com/national/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20051105000024 }} *{{cite web | URL = http://aas.org/posts/news/2015/11/astrophysical-journal-paper-retracted-plagiarism | title=Astrophysical Journal Paper Retracted for Plagiarism | date = November 24, 2015 | publisher = American Astronomical Society}} - retraction notice for Song Yoo Geun's publication in ''Astrophysical Journal'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Song, Yoo Geun}} [[Category:South Korean people]] [[Category:Inha University alumni]] [[Category:Scientific misconduct]] [[Category:Academic scandals]] [[Category:Hoaxes in science]] [[Category:1997 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Yeosan Song clan]]

page.title: Transfer admissions in the United States

revision.text:
{{Main article|College admissions in the United States}} [[File:Students work on robots at Cañada College.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Students working on a project.|Community college students are being increasingly sought after by many colleges, particularly if they earn an [[Associate Degree]], get high grades, and coordinate with counselors at their community college as well as Transfer Coordinators at their target school.]] {{Education in the U.S.}} '''Transfer admissions in the United States''' refers to college students changing universities during their college years. While estimates of transfer activity vary considerably, the consensus view is that it is substantial and increasing,<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> although media coverage of student transfers is generally less than coverage of the high school to college transition. A common transfer path is students moving from two-year community colleges to four-year institutions, although there is also considerable movement between four-year institutions. Reasons for transferring include unhappiness with campus life, cost, and course and degree selection.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> There are no standardized rules nationwide for transfers, and requirements vary by college.<ref name=twsMay2S312/> However, many states have taken steps to make the transition easier and less problematic, particularly from community colleges to four-year schools within the state, by various methods including school-to-school credit arrangements called [[Articulation (education)|articulation agreement]]s. While many state universities are constrained by budget cuts which have sometimes lessened the number of spots open to transfer students, there are reports that many private colleges are becoming more assertive in seeking transfer applicants.<ref name=twsMay2R311c>{{cite news |author= Bill Schackner |title= Transfers a hot commodity for colleges |newspaper= Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date= 2012-03-28 |url= http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/news/education/transfers-a-hot-commodity-for-colleges-240047/ |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> Nevertheless, the transfer process can be difficult, such that transfer applicants have been described as collegiate "academic nomads"<ref name=twsMay2S411/> who face various obstacles trying to make sure their credits transfer properly to their new school. Unlike admission from high school directly to college, there is less data nationwide about transfer admissions, although there are signs that this is changing.
Advisors agree that much of the advice applicable to high school applicants to college is the same for transfer applicants, such as the need for [[College tour|visiting schools]] and trying to find one which is the "right fit".<ref name=twsMay2S312/><ref name=twsMay2S115/> The admissions process for transfer students is somewhat different from that for high school seniors. Transfer applicants are more often evaluated by college grades, with standardized test results being less important. The statistical chance of being accepted into a college by a transfer arrangement was 64%, a figure slightly lower than the acceptance rate for first-year college students of 69%.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> Transferring into elite and highly selective schools is still quite difficult.
==Overview==
===Transfer pathways=== The most common transfer pathway is from two-year community colleges to four-year colleges within a state. Students beginning their collegiate education at community colleges save "enormously" on tuition,<ref name=twsMay2S315>{{cite news |title= Two years and a degree |newspaper= Washington Times |date= October 19, 2003 |url= http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2003/oct/19/20031019-115109-5642r/?page=all |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> since most live with their parents and many work full-time.<ref name=twsMay2S114/>
{{Quote|Think of us as the lowest-cost on ramp to an undergraduate degree ... Americans are pretty good at shopping price and value.|Glenn DuBois of Virginia community colleges, 2010<ref name=twsMay2S114/>}}
[[File:Barack Obama - 2008.jpg|thumb|right|250px|alt=Picture of a man holding a microphone and talking and gesturing.|United States president [[Barack Obama]], as a youth, transferred from one four-year college to another.]]
But there have been transfers occurring in the other direction, with students from private universities switching to state schools after two years, sometimes as a way to reduce cost.<ref name=twsMay2Q845>{{cite news |author= Jacques steinberg |title= Transferring to a State University, and Saving Tens of Thousands of Dollars in the Bargain |newspaper= ''The New York Times: Education'' |date= April 11, 2012 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/11/transferring-to-save/ |accessdate= May 17, 2012 }}</ref> And many students switch between four-year colleges. Some students find themselves unhappy with their current college, and decide to switch for a variety of reasons, usually having to do with a program of study or a feeling about a particular school that the "fit" is not right, or concerns over cost.<ref name=twsMay2S115>{{cite news |author= Lynda Lopez Prosser |title= College crossover: Money, campus life lead some students to transfer |newspaper= Chicago Tribune |quote= ...But some students arrive at college only to find the campus is not for them.... |date= October 8, 2009 |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2009-10-08/news/0910090374_1_college-students-transfer-high-school-students-community-colleges |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> A notable example of a high profile transfer was United States President [[Barack Obama]], who transferred from [[Occidental College]] to [[Columbia University]] during his college days.<ref name=twsMay2R311d>{{cite news |author= Kim Clark |title= Obama's Lessons for Transfer Students: His former roommate talks about what he and Obama learned about switching between colleges |newspaper= US News |date= January 16, 2009 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/articles/2009/01/16/obamas-lessons-for-transfer-students |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref>
===Demographics of transfer students=== Estimates vary considerably regarding how many college students transfer. Several reports suggested about a third of college-aged students had transferred at least once during their college careers,<ref name=twsMay2R311d/><ref name=twsMay2R311a>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Transfer Students: 8 Things You Need to Know |newspaper= US News |date= November 16, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/the-college-solution/2010/11/16/transfer-students-8-things-you-need-to-know |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsMay2S114/><ref name=twsMay2R311b>{{cite news |author= Valerie Strauss |title= New study: 1 in 3 college students transfer |newspaper= Washington Post |date= 2010-04-28 |url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/answer-sheet/college-admissions/new-study-1-in-3-college-stude.html |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> which includes transfers from community or two-year colleges to four-year colleges, as well as transfers between four-year colleges or universities.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/><ref name=twsMay2R311b/> A high estimate was that 60% of students attended more than one collegiate institution between the ages of 18 and 24, and this estimate includes 20% who transferred from one four-year institution to another one.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> A third estimate was that only 20% of students in four-year colleges were transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2S112/> A fourth estimate, from the National Center of Education Statistics, was that 2.5 million college students transferred each year.<ref name=twsMay2S115/> In 2009, one report was that 566,400 students at schools surveyed by ''[[US News]]'', transferred from one institution to another in that year.<ref name=twsMay2R311e>{{cite news |author= Katy Hopkins |title= 10 Colleges With Most Transfer Students |newspaper= US News |date= April 12, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2011/04/12/10-colleges-with-most-transfer-students |accessdate= May 18, 2012 }}</ref> A report in 1999–2000 suggested that a fifth of community college students intended to transfer to four-year colleges, and an additional 24% were taking courses for personal enrichment or for transfer purposes.<ref name=twsMay2S315/> Another report suggested that only about a quarter of community college students followed through on their plan to transfer to a four-year college or university.<ref name=twsMay2S411/>
Transfer students tend to be disproportionately from poorer families, according to one report.<ref name=twsMay2S112/> A report suggests that many transfer students have "far more experience in the ups and downs of the working world" and tend to bring more diversity to a college campus.<ref name=twsMay2S114/> A second report confirms that "transfers graduate at a higher rate than students who just finished 12th grade", and have "adjusted to a more independent lifestyle."<ref name=twsMay2S211/> Demographic analysis suggests that a slight decline in high school graduates is underway since about 2009, prompting many four-year colleges to make up for the shortfall by bringing in more transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2S411/>
===Financial considerations for transfer students=== Transfer students can get financial assistance in the form of merit aid. One estimate was that over three-quarters of colleges (77%) offer merit aid to transfer applicants. Merit aid often varies by college size: smaller colleges with less than 3,000 students were somewhat more likely to offer merit aid (81%) than medium-sized colleges (66%) or large schools (67%).<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> Greater than three-quarters of schools (77%) said that they offer merit scholarships for transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> And there are reports that the practice of offering "transfer scholarships" is becoming more prominent.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> There are reports that there is more [[Student financial aid in the United States|financial aid]] for transfer students in states such as [[New Jersey]], which have increased state funds for scholarships such as the [[Higher education in New Jersey#NJ STARS|NJ STARS II]] program.<ref name=twsMay2S211/> There was a report that less selective colleges and universities were somewhat less likely than competitive colleges to award merit scholarships to incoming transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/>
==The process of transferring==
===Obstacles and difficulties=== One reporter described the transfer process as problematic:
{{Quote|The trouble can begin during the clunky and overly complicated transfer admissions process. While students who come from community colleges are often assisted by long-standing agreements between a state's junior colleges and its flagship universities, the path for everyone else—those who are crossing state lines, who come from another four-year university, or who have spent years in the workforce—is far more treacherous. The process is difficult to navigate without the help of counselors and advisers, positions that often are left unfilled when budget cuts need to be made.|Alison Go in ''[[US News]]'', 2008<ref name=twsMay2S112/>}}
Openings for transfers vary by type of college, and can vary at a particular college year by year. One source suggested that small liberal arts colleges which have most freshmen completing all four years, tend to have few openings available; in contrast, large state universities often have many positions open, typically to accommodate graduates from two-year colleges.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> For example, 412 students applied for transfer admission into [[Amherst College]] and admitted about 6% of them;<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> in contrast, the much larger [[Arizona State University]] had 11,427 transfer applicants and admitted 84% of them. One report described transfer students as "academic nomads" struggling to keep credit hours they have earned.<ref name=twsMay2S411>{{cite news |author= Tim Barker |title= Meet the transfers - they are academic nomads: Schools, government seek to streamline system to help more students make switch to four-year colleges, keep credit hours they have earned. |newspaper= St. Louis Today |date= February 5, 2012 |url= http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/education/meet-the-transfers---they-are-academic-nomads/article_075d610e-dc58-5686-abfe-61c803e18594.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref>
Transfer students, particularly community college students, face many additional obstacles when trying to achieve their transfer goals. While attending a community college is a financially attractive choice to numerous students in the United States, studies have shown that students who enroll in community colleges are significantly less likely to complete a bachelor’s degree when compared to four-year students who started at a university as freshmen.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alfonso|first=Mariana|title=The Impact of Community College Attendance on Baccalaureate Attainment|journal=Research in Higher Education|date=December 2006|volume=47|issue=8|pages=873–903|doi=10.1007/s11162-006-9019-2|jstor=40197515}}</ref> In fact, it is estimated that only 20% of the 1992 high school class originally enrolled at a community college received a bachelor’s degree by the year 2000.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alfonso|first=Mariana|title=The Impact of Community College Attendance on Baccalaureate Attainment|journal=Research in Higher Education|date=December 2006|volume=47|issue=8|pages=873–903|jstor=40197515|doi=10.1007/s11162-006-9019-2}}</ref> Students who have a strong sense of self-efficacy, and feeling of belonging to the campus community, are more likely to persist in their studies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tinto|first=Vincent|date=2015|title=Through the Eyes of Students|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/286637525_Through_the_Eyes_of_Students|journal=Journal of College Student Retention: Research, Theory & Practice|volume=19|pages=254-269|doi=10.1177/1521025115621917|via=}}</ref> However, transfer students' confidence can be hindered by the stigma associated with having attended community college, which is perceived to be less academically rigorous.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chin-Newman|first=Christina|last2=Shaw|first2=Stacy|date=2013|title=The anxiety of change: How transfer students face challenges|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/262377028_The_anxiety_of_change_How_transfer_students_face_challenges|journal=Journal of College Admission|volume=221|pages=15–21|via=}}</ref> Another factor preventing transfer out of community colleges is the requirement of remedial courses for new students. The large need for remedial classes, especially in writing and math, has left students discouraged, as they feel they are repeating high school.<ref group=laird>{{cite news|last=Laird|first=Bob|title=The Trouble With Transferring: It Shouldn't Be So Difficult|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA196376936&v=2.1&u=saddleback_col&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w|accessdate=29 July 2013|newspaper=The Chronicle of Higher Education|year=2009}}</ref> In addition, the lack of quality academic counseling has been a problem.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gard|first=Dwight|last2=Paton|first2=Valerie|last3=Gosselin|first3=Kevin|date=2012|title=Student Perceptions of Factors Contributing to Community College-to-University Transfer Success|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10668920903182666|journal=Community College Journal of Research and Practice|volume=36|pages=833-848|via=}}</ref> Due to the fact that many community college students attend more than one college, proper advising has been hard to come by since each school has its each course numbering system.<ref>{{cite news|last=Laird|first=Bob|title=The Trouble With Transferring: It Shouldn't Be So Hard|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA196376936&v=2.1&u=saddleback_col&it=r&p=AONE&sw=w|accessdate=29 July 2013|newspaper=The Chronicle of Higher Education|year=2009}}</ref> When a student wishes to transfer to an institution out of state, the process becomes even more complicated as there may be limited articulation agreements.
The obstacles preventing two-year college students from transferring and earning a bachelor's degree may also be related to motivational and psychological issues. While work, family, and financial issues are the common factors to blame for the decline in transfer rates from community college students, research has shown that motivation to learn and succeed can make a major impact on a student's future. After examining the results from National Longitudinal Surveys, it was discovered that students entering a community college who aimed during their last few years in high school to earn a B.A. or graduate degree yielded the highest transfer rates in 1972 and 1980, the two classes of the study.<ref name=grubb>{{cite journal|last=Grubb|first=W|title=The Decline of Community College Transfer Rates: Evidence from National Longitudinal Surveys|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|date=March–April 1991|volume=62|issue=2|page=204|doi=10.2307/1982145|jstor=1982145}}</ref> While the transfer rates in this study declined, a correlation between positive educational aspirations and transfer success was noted. Additional studies have also examined the relationship of psychological and motivational factors with transfer rates. Students who have ambitious career goals are more likely to transfer, and students whose expectations don't exceed the two-year college level are less likely to transfer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Velez|first=William|author2=Rajshekhar G. Javalgi |title=Two-Year College to Four-Year College: The Likelihood of Transfer|journal=American Journal of Education|date=November 1987|volume=96|issue=1|page=89|doi=10.1086/443882|jstor=1085178}}</ref> Making significant progress and steps at a community college may also be a beneficial factor in maintaining motivation and overcoming the difficulties that transfer students face. Referring back to the results from the National Longitudinal Surveys, it was found that students who transferred without an Associate degree were less likely to complete a B.A. degree than those without one.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Grubb|first=W|title=The Decline of Community College Transfer Rates: Evidence from National Longitudinal Surveys|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|date=March–April 1991|volume=62|issue=2|page=208|doi=10.2307/1982145|jstor=1982145}}</ref>
===Researching transfer options=== Only in the past decade has the federal government begun requiring colleges to post statistics about transfer students. As a result, there is not much readily-accessible information about historical trends about transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/> The [[United States Department of Education]] did a tracking study in 2003 to analyze the progress of students who started at community colleges in that year, and found that of those planning to transfer to a four-year college, only 15% of them had actually done so within a three-year time interval.<ref name=twsMay2S411/> Record keeping and data about transfer admissions is not as complete as comparable data for freshman admissions; it varies by school. Researching transfer possibilities is generally more complex than applying to college from high school.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> Advisors suggest one method to get information about specific schools is to search online and use the [[Common Data Set]]:
{{Quote|The Common Data Set is a document that four-year schools across the country complete that contains lots of information on such topics as admission criteria, freshman academic profile, campus safety and transfer admissions. You can often find a college's Common Data Set by Googling that term and the name of the institution.|Lynn O'Shaughnessy in ''[[US News]]'', 2010<ref name=twsMay2R311a/>}}
So-called "transfer friendly" colleges which seek transfer applicants often have a transfer coordinator, housing arrangements for transfer students, an orientation program for transfer students, and are likely to accept most or all of a student's credits from their previous college.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/>
===Transferring credits=== Generally in the past, the uncertainty surrounding the issue of credit transfers has been a continuing headache for transfer applicants. An applicant might find out, belatedly, that coursework taken at one school would not be accepted at a second school. A general issue with transferring colleges is getting the new college to accept the coursework from the old one. Students often speak with the target college's transfer credit evaluator to get a sense of which credits will be accepted.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> In past years, the willingness of target colleges to approve credits was described as a "thorny proposition".<ref name=twsMay2S211/> The issue of transferring credits could be further complicated if an incoming school decided that a specific grade in the former school was insufficient for credit or if a transfer student decided to switch majors. There have been stories of students who arrived on campus with worthless transcripts:
{{Quote|There's nothing more frustrating for a transfer student than to sit down with a four-year school and realize they wasted two years because they didn't take the right classes.|Alan Byrd, admissions director at [[University of Missouri–St. Louis]], 2012<ref name=twsMay2S411/>}}
A reporter explained that community colleges do not have articulation agreements with every possible target school, and that course catalogs can not provide information about which courses will be accepted at which colleges:
{{Quote|Course catalogs offer little or no guidance to students, why one class might transfer and the other won't. But that's because each four-year school may treat a particular class differently. The University of Missouri might accept an English course rejected by the University of Kansas. There can even be differences within a campus, with a science course counting toward a general education degree but failing to satisfy a school's nursing program. As a result, it's not always clear whether a course will be accepted when a student decides to transfer.|Reporter Tim Barker in ''St. Louis Today'', 2012<ref name=twsMay2S411/>}}
Despite past difficulties with transferring credits, there are numerous reports that colleges are seeking more transfer applicants. To expedite this process, many colleges are taking steps to streamline the credit-approval process<ref name=twsMay2R311c/><ref name=twsMay2S412>{{cite news |author= Laura Diamond |title= Colleges work to improve graduation rates |newspaper=Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date= March 19, 2012 |url= http://www.ajc.com/news/georgia-government/colleges-work-to-improve-1391042.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> and are being more open-minded about accepting credits. Some colleges have "one-stop transfer centers" to make final determinations about which course credits will transfer.<ref name=twsMay2R311c/><ref name=twsMay2S211/> The [[American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers]] oversees colleges and universities and determines such matters as college accreditation, and as a result, most four-year colleges accept credits from colleges that this body approves provided that the student has earned a grade of "C" or higher in those courses.<ref name=twsMay2S315/> One advisor suggested that students should "get in touch with their target schools as early as possible to make sure their course plan will work."<ref name=twsMay2S411/> Another successful transfer strategy is for students to complete their [[Associate Degree]] which, according to one report, will "essentially guarantee that all of their credits will transfer."<ref name=twsMay2S411/>
===Statistics on acceptances=== Statistics regarding transfer admissions are becoming easier to obtain since most schools follow the [[Common Data Set]] format and post information on numerous variables on a website. However, formats vary: some schools use a spreadsheet while others use a pdf. And in some cases, the common data set information is hard to find on a college's website, or buried in a "Fast Facts" section. The data in the adjacent table is for selected colleges for the 2010–2011 year. It is average data only, and may change substantially from year to year, and from college to college. Click on the triangles to sort columns by school name, state, number of applicants, and percent acceptances.<ref>Note: many colleges had not yet posted the 2011-2012 data at the time of this chart. If contributors wish to add data for other colleges, please do so.</ref>

Oklahoma Common Data Set]</ref> |align="left"|OK |align="left"|Public |align="right"|3271 |align="right"|68 |align="right"|2015 |- |align="left"|[[Colgate University|Colgate]]<ref>[http://www.colgate.edu/docs/default-source/default-document-library/common-data-set_2015-2016.pdf?sfvrsn=2 Source: Colgate Common Data Set] Retrieved Feb 2016</ref> |align="left"|NY |align="left"|Private |align="right"|308 |align="right"|18 |align="right"|2015 |}
===Applications considerations=== [[File:Graduation hugs.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Two people hugging; one with a graduation cap.|Several reports suggest that community college applicants who transfer to four-year colleges become successful academically since they often have excellent work skills.]]
[[File:University of Arizona mall.jpg|thumb|right|400px|alt=Picture of a college campus.|The [[University of Arizona]] accepts the largest number of incoming transfer students, according to one report.]]
Most university admissions offices have an official with the designated responsibility for handling transfer admissions.<ref name=twsMay2S312>{{cite news |author= Allen Millett and Leslie Goldberg |title= E-Campus Discussion Lounge |newspaper= Washington Post |year= 1999 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-adv/liveonline/viewpoint/collink/collink120199.htm |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref><ref name=twsMay2S213>{{cite news |author= Howard and Matthew Greene |title= PBS: 'Ten Steps to College' (transcript) |newspaper= Washington Post |date= October 22, 2003 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A21178-2003Oct13.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> Transfer students have been counselled to contact the target college's "transfer coordinator" or "transfer officer".
Admissions departments, when evaluating transfer applicants, weigh the student's grade point average at their current college to a considerable extent; it is usually the single most important factor overall.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> One estimate was that 90% of colleges surveyed felt that the college grade point average was "considerably important."<ref name=twsMay2R311a/> A second source confirms that post-secondary grade point average is the "most important factor for transfer admission."<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> Other factors entering into transfer evaluations may include high school grade point average (56% of colleges consider this), recommendations and quality of current college or university programs (48%), essays or writing samples (47%), and scores on standardized tests (42%).<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> As a rule of thumb, the more time that a student has spent with his or her current college, the less another school will be interested in standardized tests taken during high school such as the [[ACT (test)|ACT test]] or [[SAT|SAT test]]. A student who has completed two-years at a community college and earned an [[Associate Degree]] often will not be asked to supply a high school record or ACT/SAT scores unless he or she earned less than 30 credits.<ref name=twsMay2S312/><ref name=twsMay2R311a/> About a tenth of colleges (11%) consider it a negative if the transfer applicant planned to only attend the new school "part-time".<ref name=twsMay2R311b/>
Transfer students are usually asked to explain why they would like to transfer, particularly when changing from one four-year college to another. One report advised applicants to avoid saying anything negative about their current school but rather to focus on specific reasons for the change.<ref name=twsMay2R311a/>
Admissions consultants Howard and Matthew Greene suggested that students should contact target schools early:
{{Quote|... if you have particular universities in mind as targets, start contacting them early to know their time schedule and particular requirements in the first two years of their program so that you can try to match up your curriculum. Be certain of specific requirements for any special school programs (business, communications, fine arts, engineering, etc.). The transfer process is typically more mature and directed, and students should have a better sense of their interests, majors, and what they're looking for. Colleges expect direct contacts from students as mature learners.|Howard and Matthew Greene, 2003<ref name=twsMay2S213/>}}
{| class="wikitable" style="float:right;" |- |+ Percent agreement by colleges of statements<br>regarding transfer admissions |- ! Statement ! % Agree |- | High school grade point average is important | 56% |- | Quality of current school is important | 48% |- | Essay or writing sample is important | 47% |- | Standardized test scores are important | 42% |- | It is a negative if a transfer applicant<br>only wants to enroll part-time | 11% |- | It is a negative if a transfer applicant<br>plans to transfer 60+ credit hours | 6% |- | It is a negative if a transfer applicant<br>earned a GED certificate | 6% |- | It is a positive if a transfer applicant<br>is attending a highly competitive college | 50% |- | It is a positive if a transfer applicant<br>earns an associates degree | 40% |- | Colleges use statistical algorithms to<br>recalculate an applicant's current college GPA | 43% |- | College provides merit scholarships<br> for transfer students | 77% |- |<small>..source: NACAC survey via ''[[Washington Post]]''</small><ref name=twsMay2R311b/> | |}
===Adjusting to a new school=== [[File:RutgersHall1462.JPG|thumb|right|300px|alt=Buildings behind trees.|[[Rutgers University]] in New Jersey has a one-credit required "course" to teach incoming transfer students about the particulars of campus life at the public university.]]
Transfer applicants sometimes have difficulty adjusting to a new school. Unlike four-year students, they often have to get acclimated to the institution at a time when they are expected to make decisions about majors and courses of study, and often have to learn new procedures and routines.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> In addition to reduced housing options, other difficulties encountered include often having to register for courses after four-year students, so many courses are filled up before a transfer student has a chance to sign up for them.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> Some universities such as [[Rutgers University]] in [[New Jersey]] have a required one-credit seminar "course" to teach incoming transfer students about university life, including topics ranging from football games to art museums, and has 25 "transfer mentor" students to help them adjust to campus life.<ref name=twsMay2S211/>
==Transferring to different types of schools==
===Transferring to a private college=== There are reports of private colleges making more active efforts to woo community college students as an effort to "bolster and diversify their enrollments".<ref name=twsMay2S113>{{cite news |author= David Moltz |title= More private colleges court community college transfers |newspaper= USA Today |date= 2010-02-18 |url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2010-02-18-IHE-transfer-students-18_ST_N.htm |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> Private college admissions departments are more likely to evaluate transfer applicants based on nonacademic variables such as the interview, recommendations, writing samples, and the quality of the applicant's current college.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> One estimate was that 40% of these schools recalculate a transfer applicant's GPA as part of the evaluation process,<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> by using algorithms to factor in perceived course difficulty and comprehensiveness. One report suggested that private schools, while they tend to be more expensive, were a "strong option for transfer students" since they were often unaffected by state budget cuts and tend to have "better counseling services."<ref name=twsMay2S112/> Private colleges often view applicants from community colleges positively since many have had a track record of finishing their four-year degrees, or what colleges term "high persistence", and being successful students with relatively high graduation rates.<ref name=twsMay2S113/> There are reports that the percentage of community college students who are transferring to private schools is increasing; in the past, the percentage was about 15% to 20%, but the figure is more likely to be higher in recent years.<ref name=twsMay2S113/>
[[File:Depaul downtown chicago.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Picture of buildings and street in urban area.|Chicago's [[DePaul University]] accepts many incoming students from community colleges.]] [[File:Union County College Phi Theta Kappa speech to inductees.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Picture of speaker making speech, with others on podium, with words "Phi Theta Kappa" on banner.|Two-year college students who belong to the academic honor society [[Phi Theta Kappa]] have excellent opportunities to transfer to many types of schools.]]
There tend to be more transfers to large private institutions, such as [[DePaul University]] in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] which accepted 1,400 transfer students in 2009, mostly from community colleges.<ref name=twsMay2S115/> In New Jersey, [[Seton Hall University]] keeps track of high school students which it accepts but who then decide to enroll in a community college, and then it sends them letters and emails after a year to try to get them to transfer; in addition, Seton Hall purchases lists of students from [[Phi Theta Kappa]], the two-year college honor society.<ref name=twsMay2S211/>
===Transferring to a public university=== [[File:OCC3-NJ.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Building in winter.|Community colleges such as [[Ocean County College]] in [[New Jersey]] often have clearly specified transfer pathways to four-year colleges within the state.]]
This is the most likely pathway for students transferring from community colleges, usually to a four-year public university within their state. About half of public universities recalculate a transfer applicant's GPA when deciding whether to admit the student.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> Often large public universities are well-suited to absorb many transfer applicants.
[[File:Gville UF old Dairy Sci bldg front01.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Picture of building behind palm trees.|Budget cuts at the [[University of Florida]] have left fewer spots open for transfer students.]] [[File:USC Bovard Auditorium.jpg|thumb|right|300px|alt=Building.|Well-endowed large private universities such as the [[University of Southern California]] have ramped up efforts to attract transfer students, according to one report.]]
However, there are numerous reports from states about constraints placed on incoming transfers because of budget cuts, although the general pattern is that states are working harder to ensure a smoother transition, with transfers of credit, from community colleges to four-year flagship schools. In [[Virginia]], the [[University of Virginia]], which has approximately 14,000 undergraduate students, had 2,434 transfer applications in 2008, and of these, admitted 958, an acceptance rate of 39%.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> In 2008 in [[Florida]], the [[University of Florida]] announced reductions in its transfer class by 33% to cope with budget shortfalls.<ref name=twsMay2S112>{{cite news |author= Alison Go |title= Transfer Students Feel the Pinch When Money Is Tight: State cuts to higher education are particularly tough for transfer students |newspaper=US News |date= August 8, 2008 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/articles/2008/08/08/transfer-students-feel-the-pinch-when-money-is-tight |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> The picture is similar in [[Minnesota]], with a report that the [[University of Minnesota]] is planning to decrease the number of transfer applicants by 8%, meaning that 300 fewer students will be able to transfer into the state's flagship college,<ref name=twsMay2S414>{{cite news |agency= Associated Press |title= U of M plans to accept fewer transfer students |newspaper= KARE 11 |date= Nov 28, 2011 |url= http://www.kare11.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=948721 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> although there is a conflicting report suggesting that enrollment at the state's university is increasing.<ref name=twsMay2S415>{{cite news |author= Jenna Ross |title= U plans modest undergrad enrollment increase |newspaper= Star-Tribune |date= October 13, 2011 |url= http://m.startribune.com/local/?id=131834373 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> At [[Maryland]]'s [[Bowie State University]], transfer applicants apply online, pay a fee of $40, ask their current college to send official transcripts of their coursework, and require a minimum of 24 transferable credits with a minimum grade point average of 2.0.<ref name=twsMay2S111>{{cite news |title= Transfer Admissions |newspaper= Bowie State University |date= May 19, 2012 |url= http://www.bowiestate.edu/admissions/transfer/ |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> Bowie considers applicants from two-year colleges differently from applicants elsewhere; two-year applicants can transfer a maximum of 65 credit hours, while applicants from four-year colleges can transfer a maximum of 90 credit hours.<ref name=twsMay2S111/> Applicants with fewer than 24 transferable credits must meet the requirements for freshman admission, which includes having their high school transcript and SAT/ACT scores sent.<ref name=twsMay2S111/> Large "well-endowed" private universities such as the [[University of Southern California]] and [[New York University]] have "ratcheted up" efforts to recruit community college transfers to help them improve their "demographic mix":
{{Quote|It helps the selective privates with their diversity, in terms of race and socioeconomic status ... To get students in certain income brackets, it matters. Oftentimes it's easier to recruit at community colleges than at challenged high schools. For those who value diversity, whether it's because of the college rankings or their mission, this is where you go.|Sociologist Josipa Roksa of the [[University of Virginia]].<ref name=twsMay2S113/>}}
===Transferring to an elite university=== [[File:Amherst College College Row.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Building.|[[Amherst College]] accepts very few transfer applicants.]]
A general picture is that elite colleges and universities accept very few transfer applications and are "extremely picky", generally because most of their enrolled students continue through all four years without changing to another school or dropping out, and there are few empty slots to fill. For example, [[Yale University]] had 751 transfer applications in 2008, and accepted only 24 of these.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> [[Harvard University]] has not accepted any transfer students in the last few years; [[Columbia University|Columbia]] accepted only 8% in 2007, and the [[University of Pennsylvania]] accepted only 16% in 2008.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> These schools are more likely to consider such factors as the quality of the applicant's high school and current college, as well as factors such as the applicant's state and county of residence, race and ethnicity, and alumni relations.<ref name=twsMay2R311b/> One report suggested the essay was highly important, and that an applicant should explain why they wished to change schools.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> Generally, elite schools do not look favorably on students who try to "trade up" to a more "prestigious bumper sticker."<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> Successful transfers into elite schools have "great grades and test scores,"<ref name=twsMay2R311d/> and students usually transfer from other elite schools. Some top schools such as [[Cornell University]] have articulation agreements specifying how a community college student can transfer into Cornell by taking specific courses and getting good grades in them.<ref name=twsMay2R311d/>
===Transferring within a state=== The consensus view is that transferring from a two-year college to a four-year college—within one state—is smoother than transfers from one state to another.<ref name=twsMay2S112/> Since community and two-year college programs are often supported by government subsidies at the county or state level, and lawmakers strive to increase educational opportunities for students within their state, there have been many efforts by state legislatures and administrators in flagship universities to facilitate the switch-over from two-year to four-year colleges within each state. In addition, many state colleges standardize their requirements for incoming transfer students, which helps to expedite intrastate transfers. For example, the [[California State University]] system gives priority to community college students transferring to four-year colleges within California; one estimate was that 60% of students on its 23 different campuses were transfer students.<ref name=twsMay2R311e/> The [[University of California]] has an arrangement to accept many students conditionally to one of its 10 undergraduate campuses if students first complete two years of community college; the plan extended these so-called "provisional offers of admission" to 12,700 students in the year 2000 (before the [[University of California, Merced|tenth campus]] opened).<ref name=twsMay2S212>{{cite news |author= Kenneth r. weiss |title= UC Chief Offers Plan to Boost Minority Enrollment -- Proposal: Students would be accepted on the condition that they first complete two years of community college. |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= September 21, 2000 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/paper-trail/2008/03/21/harvard-halts-transfers-for-two-years/comments |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> In 2010, there were reports that 33,700 students were trying to transfer into the University of California system, but that uncertain state funding issues were complicating matters.<ref name=twsMay2S311>{{cite news |author= Larry Gordon |title= Waiting lists to be established at most UC campuses, regents say: The lists will give the university more flexibility to remain within enrollment targets in the face of fiscal uncertainty. |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |date= January 21, 2010 |url= http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/21/local/la-me-uc21-2010jan21 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> A report in 2012 suggested that "explosive growth in the number of applications" along with cuts in state funding had prevented the [[University of California, San Diego]] from continuing their [[Transfer Admission Guarantee]] program.<ref name=twsMay2S314>{{cite news |title= U-T: UCSD Ends Community College Transfer Guarantee: TAG Program Guaranteed Admission To Community College Students |newspaper= 10 News (San Diego News0 |date= May 2, 2012 |url= http://www.10news.com/news/30991999/detail.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref>
Generally, large state universities are well-suited to offer [[Higher education in the United States|higher education]] to transfer applicants from within their state as well as elsewhere.<ref name=twsMay2R311e/> The largest state university to enroll transfer students was [[Arizona State University]], according to one report, which enrolled 5,388 transfer students in 2009.<ref name=twsMay2R311e/> Many two-year community or county colleges have longstanding [[Articulation (education)|articulation agreement]]s with the flagship universities within their states about accepting transfer applicants. [[Indiana]] has been successful in shunting students from its [[Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana|Ivy Tech community colleges]] to its four-year colleges and that successful transfers, including transfers of credits, has risen 438 percent during the past ten years.<ref name=twsMay2S512>{{cite news |title= Ivy Tech transferring more students to 4-year colleges |newspaper= Indianapolis Recorder |date= Sep 1, 2011 |url= http://www.indianapolisrecorder.com/news/print_highlights/article_fefc90ba-d4d4-11e0-bfe3-001cc4c03286.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> There are reports that states such as [[Virginia]] and [[Maryland]] have made efforts to build a "transfer pipeline" from community colleges to public universities to the extent that it was "changing the traditional path to a four-year degree."<ref name=twsMay2S114>{{cite news |author= Daniel de Vise |title= Community-college transfer students in Va., Md., easing into university level |newspaper= Washington Post |date= June 17, 2010 |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/16/AR2010061605737.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> [[Virginia]] has a system in which students at any of its 23 community colleges who earn an Associates Degree have a "guaranteed transfer" to one of the state's highly ranked colleges and universities such as [[Virginia Commonwealth University]] in Richmond.<ref name=twsMay2S413>{{cite news |author= Michael rao |title= Virginia is ready to invest in higher ed |newspaper= Richmond Times-Dispatch (VCU=> Virginia Commonwealth University) |date= January 3, 2012 |url= http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/rtd-opinion/2012/jan/03/tdopin02-virginia-is-ready-to-invest-in-higher-ed-ar-1582643/ |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> [[Maryland]] has an online database so that community college students can know the transfer value of each course.<ref name=twsMay2S114/> In tight economic times, the path of a relatively inexpensive two-year community college followed by a somewhat more expensive two years at a four-year public university, is often a more realistic choice for cash-strapped families.<ref name=twsMay2S114/> [[Frostburg State University]] has worked on agreements with community colleges to make the transfer between the two schools "smoother".<ref name=twsMay2S313>{{cite news |title= Officials sign admissions pact: Student transfers between the two schools should be smoother |newspaper= Herald-Mail |date= March 2, 2009 |url= http://articles.herald-mail.com/2009-03-02/news/25171364_1_student-transfer-admissions-pact |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> [[Minnesota]], as well, has outlined its policy of "transfer rights and responsibilities" to smooth the transition.<ref name=twsMay2S511>{{cite news |author= Jenna Ross |title= On campus beat: MnSCU outlines transfer rights |newspaper= Star Tribune |date= May 15, 2012 |url= http://www.startribune.com/local/151624575.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> The policy insists students have a right to "clear, accurate and current information" about transfer policies including deadline, requirements for degrees, and course equivalencies, while at the same time insisting that students have a duty to enroll in transfer workshops, speak with advisors, and plan out their path towards degrees.<ref name=twsMay2S511/> In [[New Jersey]], there were reports of many residents transferring to in-state schools in "record numbers" in 2009, and that many transfer students were considered to be "prize catches" since they had developed a track record of educational achievement at other schools in neighboring states and around the country.<ref name=twsMay2S211>{{cite news |author= Carly Rothman |title= College students from N.J. transferring to in-state schools in record numbers |newspaper= The Star-Ledger |date= August 10, 2009 |url= http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2009/08/college_students_from_nj_trans.html |accessdate= May 19, 2012 }}</ref> New Jersey's [[List of New Jersey County Colleges|19 community colleges]] serve approximately 400,000 students, and 61% of them transfer to four-year schools.<ref name=twsMay2S211/>
===International transfers=== It is possible to transfer to many US universities from universities in other countries. According to the US-UK [[Fulbright Commission]], it is up to the university departments to which the student transfers to decide how much credit courses completed at the previous university are worth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulbright.org.uk/study-in-the-usa/undergraduate-study/applying/transfer-admissions |title=Transfer Admissions | Undergraduate Study in the USA | US-UK Fulbright Commission |publisher=Fulbright.org.uk |date=2010-11-16 |accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref>
