page.title: Use of social network websites in investigations

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Bornrealist123|Bornrealist123]] ([[User talk:Bornrealist123|talk]]) to last version by KolbertBot
revision.text:
[[Social network service]]s are increasingly being used in legal and [[criminal investigation]]s. Information posted on sites such as [[Instagram]], [[Orkut]] and [[Facebook]] has been used by police and university officials to prosecute users of said sites. In some situations, content posted on Instagram has been used in court to determine an appropriate sentence based on a defendant's attitude.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://click4like.com/ |title=Increase Facebook Likes, Twitter Followers |work=Click4Like.com. |accessdate=14 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://click4like.com/ |title=Social Marketing |work=Click4Like.com |date=5 April 1992}}</ref> The U.S. DOT National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has made federal grants available to states to train law enforcement officers to use social media sites to identify events that may result in impaired driving or consumption by minors. As of 2012, Michigan spent over $4.5 million through this program, and has trained over 100 local police officers to use social media cites to identify and target events.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nhtsa.gov/links/StateDocs/FY12/FY12ARs/MI_FY12AnnualReport.pdf | title=Michigan Office of Highway Safety Planning 2012 Annual Evaluation Report (pp. 21) | date=2012 | accessdate=2014-05-20}}</ref>
==Facebook== Facebook, a [[social network service]], is increasingly being used by school administrations and [[law enforcement agency|law enforcement agencies]] as a source of evidence against student users. The site, a popular online destination for college students, allows users to create profile pages with personal details. In the early years of the site, these pages could be viewed by other registered users from the same school, including [[resident assistant]]s, [[campus police]], or others who signed up for the service. The [[Privilege (computing)|user privileges]] and [[terms of service]] of the site have since been changed to allow users to control who has the ability to view their content.
Recent disciplinary actions against students based on information made available on Facebook has spurred debate over the legality and ethics of school administrators' harvesting such information. Facebook's [http://www.facebook.com/terms.php Terms of Use] specify that "the website is available for your personal, noncommercial use only," misleading some to believe that college administrators and police may not use the site for conducting investigations. However, Facebook spokespeople have made clear that Facebook is a public forum and all information published on the site should be presumed available to the general public, school administrators included. Legal experts agree that public information sources such as Facebook can be legally used in criminal or other investigations.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.browndailyherald.com/media/paper472/news/2005/11/03/CampusWatch/The-Facebook.Not.Just.For.Students-1044229.shtml | title=The Facebook: not just for students | date=2005-11-03 | accessdate=2006-10-14}}</ref>
In the aftermath of the [[2011 Vancouver Stanley Cup riot]], community participation in assisting police to identify the rioters has been described as unprecedented.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globaltvbc.com/Vancouver+riots+2011+Crown+look+potential+charges/4976048/story.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004041852/http://www.globaltvbc.com/Vancouver+riots+2011+Crown+look+potential+charges/4976048/story.html |archivedate=2011-10-04 |title=Vancouver riots 2011: Crown to look at potential charges |publisher=Global News |date=2011-06-20 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} </ref> Police admitted to being overwhelmed by the amount of evidence provided by social media.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2011/06/20/bc-vancouver-police-riot.html? | title=Police overwhelmed by social media evidence | date=2011-06-20 | accessdate=2011-06-20 | work=CBC News}} </ref>
===Alcohol policy violations=== It has become increasingly common for colleges and universities to use Facebook to investigate [[underage drinking]] and violations of [[dry campus]] policies. Students who violate these policies may be discovered through photographs of illicit drinking behavior, membership in drinking-related groups, or party information posted on the Facebook website. Some examples of such investigations are listed below:
*In October 2005, pictures from Facebook were used to cite violators of university alcohol policy at [[North Carolina State University]]. Charges included underage drinking and violations of the dormitory alcohol policy, specifically holding open bottles of alcoholic beverages in the dorm hallway. A dorm resident advisor originally wrote up citations for 14 different students, some of which were dropped. Details were not released by the university, but the incident received news coverage including articles in the official school newspaper and segments on local TV stations.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051031084848/http://www.wral.com/news/5204275/detail.html |work=WRAL.com|title= NCSU Students Face Underage Drinking Charges Due To Online Photos|date=October 29, 2005|url=http://www.wral.com/news/5204275/detail.html|archivedate=October 31, 2005 }}</ref> *In November 2005, four students at [[Northern Kentucky University]] were fined for posting pictures of a drinking party on Facebook. The pictures, taken in one of NKU's dormitories, proved that the students were in violation of the university's dry campus policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenortherner.com/news/2005/11/02/facebook-postings-photos-incriminate-dorm-party-goers/|work=The Northerner|title=Facebook postings, photos incriminate dorm party-goers|date=November 2, 2005|author= Chalfant, Drew}}</ref> * In November 2005, [[Emory University]] officials cited members of the [[Facebook group]] "Dobbs 2nd Alcoholics," referring to the second floor of a campus residence hall, for conduct code violations. A similar drinking group, "Wooddruff=Wasted," was also investigated. The group's club members only discussed "having fun in Wooddruff" and said no photos of students were ever posted on Facebook.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tmcnet.com/usubmit/2006/03/29/1518943.htm|title=Officials at institutions nationwide using Facebook site|date=March 29, 2006|work=TMCNet.com}}</ref> * In response to the monitoring, some students have begun to submit "[[Red herring (plot device)|red herring]]" party listings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boingboing.net/2006/01/09/facebook_prank_on_po.html|title=Facebook prank on police|work=Boing Boing|date=January 9, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060111075622/http://www.boingboing.net/2006/01/09/facebook_prank_on_po.html|archivedate=January 11, 2006|author=Pescovitz, David}}</ref> In one case at [[George Washington University]], students advertised their party and were raided by campus police. The police found only cake, no alcohol, and later claimed the dorm raid had been triggered by a noise complaint.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051004133455/http://www.collegehumor.com/pictures/1607781/|title=How much cake is an inordinate amount? Because I can eat a lot of cake. CASE CLOSED.|type=CollegeHumor picture|url=http://www.collegehumor.com/pictures/1607781/|author=BennyChains|archivedate=October 4, 2005}}</ref>
===Other investigations=== *In December 2004, ''[[The Student Life]]'' (the [[student newspaper]] at [[Pomona College]] in [[Claremont, California]]) reported that an assistant football coach at the college had been living in the team's equipment room and hosting parties there. The paper cited postings by football players on a Facebook group page titled "We Miss Coach Baker" as evidence of the alleged parties.<ref>{{cite magazine|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041213060242/http://www.tsl.pomona.edu/index.php?article=385|archivedate=December 13, 2004|title= Football Coaches Living, Partying in Rains Equipment Room|work=The Student Life|url=http://www.tsl.pomona.edu/index.php?article=385|author=Antenen, Jay|date=December 3, 2004|volume=116|number=10}}</ref> *In October 2005, sophomore Cameron Walker was [[Expulsion (academia)|expelled]] from [[Fisher College]] in [[Boston]] for comments about a campus police officer made on Facebook. These comments, including the statement that the officer "loves to antagonize students...and needs to be eliminated," were judged to be in violation of the college's code of conduct.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2005/10/06/fisher_college_expels_student_over_website_entries/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=Fisher College expels student over website entries | first=Sarah | last=Schweitzer | date=2005-10-06}}</ref> *In November 2005, [[Kansas State University]] authorities announced that they were using Facebook to investigate a possible violation of the school's [[honor code]] potentially involving over 100 students. Students used the message board of a Facebook group to share class information without authorization from the professor.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319042926/http://www.kstatecollegian.com/article.php?a=8004|title=Facebook involved in possible Honor Pledge violation|date=November 17, 2005|author=Kennedy, Owen|work=Kansas State Collegian|archivedate=March 19, 2006 |url=http://www.kstatecollegian.com/article.php?a=8004}}</ref> *In October 2005, [[Pennsylvania State University]] police used Facebook to track down students who rushed the field after the October 8 [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]] game. Two students were later charged with criminal trespass for their involvement.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051208010655/http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/2005/11/11-10-05tdc/11-10-05dnews-09.asp|title=Site used to aid investigations|author=Lash, Devon|archivedate=December 8, 2005|date=November 10, 2005|work=The Digital Collegian|url=http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/2005/11/11-10-05tdc/11-10-05dnews-09.asp}}</ref> *In January 2006, [[Syracuse University]]'s student newspaper, ''[[The Daily Orange]]'', featured an article about a student who claimed Syracuse City Police personally warned him in advance about having a party he had listed on Facebook. The university denied the allegations and stated that their own [[peace officer]]s would have handled the case in any event.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118160331/http://www.dailyorange.com/media/paper522/news/2006/01/25/News/Su.Officials.Use.Of.Facebook.Creates.Problems.For.Students.With.A.False.Sense.Of-1503587.shtml?norewrite|work=The Daily Orange|url=http://www.dailyorange.com/media/paper522/news/2006/01/25/News/Su.Officials.Use.Of.Facebook.Creates.Problems.For.Students.With.A.False.Sense.Of-1503587.shtml?norewrite|archivedate=November 18, 2007|title=SU officials' use of Facebook creates problems for students with a false sense of privacy|author=Pepitone, Julianne|date=January 25, 2006}}</ref> * In February 2006, ''The Daily Orange'' reported about another Syracuse University incident, in which four students were placed on disciplinary probation after creating a group entitled "Clearly [instructor's first name] doesn't know what she's doing ever." The group featured derogatory and personal attacks aimed at the instructor. After meeting with judicial affairs, the students admitted that their comments on the site were inappropriate and accepted an agreement that they would not contact the instructor again.<ref>{{cite web|work=The Daily Orange|url=http://dailyorange.com/2006/02/kicked-in-the-face-freshmen-claim-judicial-affairs-threatened-expulsion-for-creation-of-facebook-group-critical-of-ta/|date= February 7, 2006|title=Kicked in the face: Freshmen claim Judicial Affairs threatened expulsion for creation of Facebook group critical of TA|author=Pepitone, Julianne}}</ref> * In February 2006, police in Oxford, Ohio were directed to the Facebook profile of a [[Miami University]] student because it showed the [[Facial composite|police sketch]] of a suspect in the [[rape]] of another Miami University student as the account owner's personal picture. The police arrested the student and charged him with inducing panic.<ref>{{cite news |title=Student arrested for inducing panic with Facebook picture |date=February 9, 2006 |author=Wolfe, Graham |publisher=[[The Miami Student]] |url=http://miamistudent.net/?p=107571 |accessdate=20 May 2015 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * Students that had created a Facebook group to complain about a professor's teaching shortcomings at the [[University of Louisville]] were responsible in part for dismissal of that instructor in February 2006. The students were not punished.<ref>{{cite web |title=Opinion: Students should voice their rights in the classroom |date=February 6, 2006 |url=http://www.louisvillecardinal.com/2.6451/editorial-1.727846 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726073422/http://www.louisvillecardinal.com/2.6451/editorial-1.727846 |archivedate=26 July 2011 |work=[[The Louisville Cardinal]] }}</ref> * Pictures posted of unrelated parties thrown by students at the [[University of Connecticut School of Law]] and [[Baylor University]] drew attention to the presence of uninstitutionalized racism on both campuses. In March 2006, Baylor’s student newspaper reported a call to action made by outraged students after pictures were posted on Facebook depicting partygoers wearing bandanas and carrying 40-ounce beer bottles wrapped in brown paper, with one young woman sporting layers of bronzer to darken her skin. An advisor for a campus fraternity denied the party was sponsored by the organization and said the party theme was not to dress "ghetto", as critics alleged, but as [[E-Dawg]], a Seattle rapper. Facebook removed the photos from the site as black student groups called for a university-sponsored open forum to discuss the racially insensitive undercurrent on campus.<ref>{{cite news | last =Amos | first =Meredith | title =Baylor U. students outraged by off-campus party | work =The Lariat | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =March 1, 2006 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref> Similar action was taken with the UConn pictures, which depicted a "Bullets and Bubbly" themed party held days after [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] Day in 2007. Half the partygoers brought champagne and dressed in formalwear for the "bubbly" portion of the theme, while the other half brought 40 ounces and dressed in do-rags, baggy hip-hop inspired clothing, gold teeth, and in some cases carried fake machine guns. The university responded by holding an open forum discussing the insensitive nature of the party and resulting photos. Controversy over similar parties has also occurred at [[Clemson University]] (South Carolina), [[Tarleton State University]] (Texas), [[Texas A&M University]], and the [[University of Chicago]].<ref>{{cite news | last =Larsen | first =Lindsay | title =U. Connecticut law school party causes stir over stereotypes | work =The Daily Campus | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =February 2, 2007 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref>
* In April 2006, [[University of Dayton]] student Christopher Herbert was fined approximately $10,000 for damages caused by an annual event known as "LowesFest." Herbert had posted a public invitation to the event on Facebook, though he did not attend the event himself. The University informed him 24 hours before "LowesFest" that he would have to pay for any and all extra costs (police, cleaning, etc.) stemming from that evening. However, Christopher Herbert chose to not pay the fine and he transferred out of the University of Dayton.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110711013400/http://flyernews.com/articles/volume/53/issue/39/category/opinion/id/2659 Flyer News - Junior unfairly blamed for Lowesfest problems]</ref> * In April 2006, officials at the [[State University of New York at Cobleskill]] took a student from [[Sri Lanka]], Tharindu Meepegama into custody after Meepegama posted pictures of him with a shotgun and wrote comments that the school officials found "troubling". Meepegama, who was later allowed to return to the school, said it was all a misunderstanding.<ref name="news observer">{{cite news | last =Locke | first =Mandy | title =Photos online brew trouble | work =[[Raleigh News and Observer]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =July 15, 2007 | url = http://www.newsobserver.com/news/crime_safety/strickland/story/637859-p2.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081204134906/http://www.newsobserver.com/news/crime_safety/strickland/story/637859-p2.html | archivedate = 2008-12-04 | accessdate = 2008-11-01 }} </ref>
* In August 2006, police officers at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] arrested two students who were spotted urinating in public. One of the students ran, and the other was apprehended by police. When queried about the identity of the student who ran, the student in custody lied saying he did not know him. The arresting officer, upon talking with witnesses, obtained the name of the student who ran. He later found that the two were Facebook friends, and therefore that the questioned student had lied. This student was charged with obstruction of justice.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516045506/http://media.www.dailyillini.com/media/storage/paper736/news/2006/08/01/News/Student.Arrested.After.Police.Facebook.Him-2142717.shtml|title=Student arrested after police Facebook him|author=Martinez, Kiyoshi|date=August 1, 2006|archivedate=May 16, 2007|work=The Daily Illini|url=http://media.www.dailyillini.com/media/storage/paper736/news/2006/08/01/News/Student.Arrested.After.Police.Facebook.Him-2142717.shtml}}</ref> * In October 2006, a male [[Southern Illinois University]] student faced possible expulsion for creating a Facebook page detailing his sexual relationship with a young female he’d been involved with in the past. Other male students added to the page with their own experiences with the woman, until she brought it to the attention of Facebook administrators, who permanently removed the page. The 19-year-old female cited slander while the young man claimed it was an inside joke and assumed she would understand the humor. In an interview he stated, "I never thought something on Facebook would get me into trouble out in the real world." During the debacle, his fellow students created yet another Facebook page with updates on the controversy.<ref>{{cite news | last =Jadhav | first =Adam |author2=Shane Graber | title =Students learning dangers of Web 'confession'; Sophomore may be expelled for Facebook page | work =The Record | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =October 5, 2006 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref>
* In December 2006, campus police at the [[University of North Carolina at Wilmington]] were investigating the theft of two [[PlayStation]] consoles, which had been stolen by the two perpetrators of a beating and robbery on campus. They planned to raid the rented house of Peyton Strickland, an 18-year-old student at nearby [[Cape Fear Community College]]. They discovered that the other alleged robber, Ryan Mills, had posted photographs of himself on Facebook in which he posed with guns. Expecting "heavily armed resistance" at Strickland's house, the officers called in a [[SWAT team]] for backup to raid Strickland's house. When they arrived at the residence, which three students rented, they were not immediately let in. As one officer began to break down the door with a [[battering ram]], another officer mistook the sound of the battering ram for gunshots and shot through the glass door multiple times, killing the unarmed Strickland and his dog.<ref name="news observer"/> The officer, Christopher Long, was not charged with second-degree [[murder]] by two different [[grand jury|grand juries]].<ref name="news observer"/> He was however initially indicted by one grand jury, which was later attributed to a clerical error and overturned. Soon after the incident, Christopher Long went on to receive $1,000 paid out by the sheriff he worked under as well as receiving a "Local Hero" award for $4000.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401103540/http://www.wwaytv3.com/node/1074|title=Former deputy to benefit from charity tournament|archivedate=April 1, 2007|url=http://www.wwaytv3.com/node/1074|date=March 28, 2007|author= WWAY|work= WWAY NewsChannel 3 }}</ref> * In January 2007, several Ottawa employees of [[Farm Boy]] were terminated due to their postings on a Facebook group titled "I Got Farm Boy'd."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/2007/01/17/3394584-sun.html|work=CANOE|title=Workers fired over Internet postings|date=January 17, 2007|first=Laura|last=Czekaj|access-date=2007-02-13|archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091015153407/http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/2007/01/17/3394584%2Dsun.html|archive-date=2009-10-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * In January 2007, a long-standing debate over the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]]'s dancing [[Chief Illiniwek]] mascot intensified after racist remarks about [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] were discovered on a pro-mascot Facebook group. The group, entitled "If They Get Rid of the Chief, I'm Becoming a Racist," contained wall posts by students that said things like, "What they don't realize is that there never was a racist problem before...but now I hate redskins and hope all those drunk casino owning bums die." Another student directed a post towards a particularly vocal Native American grad student, saying, "I say we throw a tomahawk into her face."<ref>{{cite news | last =Mercer | first =David | title =University of Ill. Investigates threats against American Indian | agency =Associated Press | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =January 10, 2007 | url = | accessdate = }} </ref> The page was removed, but not before inciting a university investigation into the threats and spawning a counter group entitled "The Chief Dance is Racist, Plain and Simple".
* In February 2007, 11 students at [[Robert F. Hall Catholic Secondary School]] in [[Caledon, Ontario]] were suspended after posting comments about their principal on Facebook.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2007/02/12/school-facebook.html| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070214121211/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2007/02/12/school-facebook.html| archivedate=2007-02-14 | work=CBC News | title=11 Ontario students suspended for 'cyber-bullying' | date=2007-02-12}}</ref> * In February 2007, following the fatal [[Hit and run (vehicular)|hit-and-run]] death of freshman Carlee Wines, [[University of Connecticut]] campus police said they used Facebook to link the suspected driver, Anthony P. Alvino of Lindenhurst, N.Y., to the university. By following leads via Facebook, police learned of the connection between Alvino and his girlfriend, Michele A. Hall, a UConn student.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.www.dailycampus.com/media/storage/paper340/news/2007/02/16/News/Two-Arrests.Made-2725647.shtml|title=Two Arrests Made|author=Carra, Nicholas|date=February 16, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070219121310/http://media.www.dailycampus.com/media/storage/paper340/news/2007/02/16/News/Two-Arrests.Made-2725647.shtml|archivedate=February 19, 2007|deadurl=y|work=The Daily Campus}}</ref> The Long Island, N.Y. newspaper ''Newsday'' reported: "Police traced Alvino's connection to UConn through his entry in Facebook, which listed Hall as his girlfriend."<ref>{{cite news |title=Arrests in hit-and-run, LI teen charged with causing death of a student at UConn; passenger, also from LI, faces charges, too |author=Merritt, Grace E. |date=Feb 16, 2007 |url=http://www.newsday.com/news/printedition/longisland/ny-lihit165095931feb16,0,2479015.story?coll=ny-linews-print |archiveurl=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/newsday/doc/280112266.html |archivedate=Feb 16, 2007 |work=[[Newsday]] }}</ref> Alvino was charged for the hit-and-run, while Hall was charged with helping cover it up and hindering prosecution.<ref>{{cite news |title=My God. What Do I Do? |author=Merritt, Grace E. |date=February 16, 2007 |url=http://articles.courant.com/2007-02-16/news/0702160821_1_uconn-freshman-affidavits-donna-alvino |work=[[Hartford Courant]] |accessdate=20 May 2015 }}</ref> *In April 2007, just days after the [[Virginia Tech]] [[Virginia Tech massacre|shooting]], a student at the [[State University of New York at Cobleskill|SUNY College at Cobleskill]] was remanded into psychiatric care and suspended from college after posting a photo of himself on his profile with a vaguely threatening message underneath.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.thedailystar.com/news/stories/2007/04/26/aa425coby10.html|title=SUNY Cobleskill student says his Internet posting troubled officials|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716231315/http://old.thedailystar.com/news/stories/2007/04/26/aa425coby10.html|archivedate=July 16, 2011|deadurl=y|date=April 26, 2007|author=Amy L. Ashbridge|work=The Daily Star}}</ref> *In October 2008, in [[Edmonton, Alberta]], it was revealed that filmmaker Mark Twitchell, who was facing first degree murder charges, had posted as his Facebook status in August that "he had a lot in common with [[Dexter Morgan]]". This proved to be a key piece of evidence in the missing person case of John Altinger, as Twitchell was a fan of the television series "[[Dexter (TV series)|Dexter]]" and it is believed that he murdered Altinger in the style of Dexter's clandestine murders. Shortly after Altinger's disappearance, Twitchell gained access to Altinger's e-mail and Facebook accounts, changing Altinger's Facebook status and e-mailing Altinger's contacts stating that he met a girl online and was planning a move to [[Costa Rica]].<ref>{{cite news|title='Dexter' murder case raises alarms over pop-culture violence |author=Reid, Michael D. |date=November 6, 2008 |url=http://article.wn.com/view/2008/11/06/Dexter_murder_case_raises_alarms_over_popculture_violence/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nationalpost.com/rss/story.html?id=927337&p=2|title=Bizarre slaying mirrored TV show: police|work=The National Post}} {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><!-- not on archive.org and other archive services. the archives at national post only go so far --> *In July 2009, an [[emergency medical technician]] in [[New York City]] was terminated and arrested for taking a picture of a crime scene and uploading it to Facebook. The technician, 46-year-old Frank Musarella, was charged with "official misconduct".<ref>{{cite news|author=Joshua Rhett Miller|title=Graphic Photo Posted on Facebook at Center of Pending Lawsuit|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,535461,00.html|date=2009-07-29|accessdate=2009-08-02|publisher=[[Fox News]]}}</ref> *Nathalie Blanchard, a Quebec woman on long-term sick leave for depression, sued [[Manulife]] after the insurer cut her benefits, claiming that her photos posted on Facebook demonstrated that she had recovered. Blanchard said that she was following her doctor's advice to try to have fun, including nights out at her local bar with friends and short getaways to sun destinations, as a way to forget her problems. She also stated that she had notified Manulife that she was taking a trip.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/11/19/quebec-facebook-sick-leave-benefits.html| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121222247/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/11/19/quebec-facebook-sick-leave-benefits.html| archivedate=2009-11-21 | work=CBC News | title=Depressed woman loses benefits over Facebook photos | date=2009-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34089972/ns/world_news-weird_news/|title=Woman loses benefits over Facebook pics|work=NBC News|date=November 23, 2009}}</ref> Some experts noted that the privacy controls on Facebook and other social networking sites was "laughable".<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091126004213/https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5jo36kPKynkgEGHOyNdSuSRdAGHuQ|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5jo36kPKynkgEGHOyNdSuSRdAGHuQ|archivedate=November 26, 2009|title= Quebec woman's Facebook insurance battle highlights need for online prudence|date=November 23, 2009|first=Sidhartha|last=Banerjee|work=The Canadian Press}}</ref> *On October 27, 2010 in Kanata Centrum, [[Ottawa]], a collector's edition [[hazelle]] jersey and a cap were stolen from an apparel store by four young males. In 15 minutes, the staff were able to use the store's [[friends list]] of 324 people who "like" the store and recognized the face of the perpetrators. Police were contacted, found the suspects, and the jersey valued at $1000.00 was recovered.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/31102010/71/central-facebook-helps-store-owner-track-thief.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101104012627/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/31102010/71/central-facebook-helps-store-owner-track-thief.html | archivedate = 2010-11-04 | title = Facebook helps store owner track thief | accessdate = 2010-11-01 | last = Butler | first = Don | date = 31 October 2010 | work = Yahoo News}}</ref> *On March 17, 2012, [[San Marino|San Marinan]] singer [[Valentina Monetta]] was selected to sing [[Facebook Uh, Oh, Oh]] for [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]]. People who were on the social network pointed out that the lyrics contained a commercial message for Facebook. The lyrics of the song that contained references to Facebook were banned from the contest on March 18. The banned lyrics must be replaced no later than March 22. If the banned lyrics are not replaced, Valentina's other song will be selected on that day. *In July 2017, the Philippine [[National Bureau of Investigation (Philippines)|National Bureau of Investigation]] is monitoring any activity of Pastor Hokage groups, after complaints from victims that their photos have been shared without permission.<ref>http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/hashtag/content/616746/pastor-hokage-fb-groups-trading-lewd-photos-of-women-exposed/story/</ref><ref>http://kickerdaily.com/posts/2017/07/ambag-pa-more-nbi-investigating-4-pastor-hokage-suspects-amid-complaints/</ref><ref>http://kickerdaily.com/posts/2017/07/woman-harassed-by-pastor-hokage-fb-group-comes-out-files-complaint/</ref>{{cn|date=July 2017}}
===Student government=== * In October 2005, [[University of Pennsylvania]] freshmen student government election results were delayed due to early campaigning violations on Facebook. Though candidates were forbidden from campaigning before a certain date, many Facebook advocacy groups appeared before that date.<ref>{{Citation|last=Wissner|first=Jennie|title=Accused students defend actions: Final results will not be released until NEC finishes deliberations|url=http://www.thedp.com/article/2005/10/accused_students_defend_actions|accessdate=May 27, 2015|newspaper=[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]]|date=October 3, 2005|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150527133045/http://www.thedp.com/article/2005/10/accused_students_defend_actions|archive-date=May 27, 2015}}</ref> The [[University of California, Berkeley]], [[High Point University]], and [[The George Washington University]] have also experienced similar problems. {{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
===Cyber-bullying=== Facebook and other social networking sites are being used to bring [[bullying]] outside of school. Students are being targeted on the internet and even mobile devices. A new strategy to catch cyber-bullies is being implemented in [[Reading, Berkshire]]: * From February 28, 2011 until May 2011, [[Thames Valley Police]] Officers will be using Facebook to catch cyber-bullies. With the help of a teenage volunteer, the police will go through Facebook pages to investigate reported instances of [[cyber-bullying]]. If there is anything inappropriate found, a Facebook message will be sent to the offender which will warn them of the consequences of bullying. Along with the message, the student's parents will also receive a letter highlighting the incident and the potential consequences.<ref>[https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-02/28/police-facebook Thames Valley Police to use Facebook to catch cyberbullies (Wired UK)<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020141/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-02/28/police-facebook |date=2016-03-05 }}</ref> * In May 2012, Lake Havasu Unified School District #1 used evidence found on Facebook to catch multiple cyber-bullies after a discussion on a post that the one who felt bullied was not involved in. The school district acquired the list of comments through another student, who printed them out and handed them in to the school administration.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}} *In Bangalore, India, school students of certain schools were all asked to delete their Facebook profiles in the wake of cyber bullying.<ref>[http://www.ndtv.com/article/cities/no-facebook-bangalore-schools-ask-students-to-delete-profiles-435723 No Facebook! Bangalore schools ask students to delete profiles | NDTV.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Indian law addresses some of the components of cyber-bullying. However, the perpetrators are children and therefore alternatives to criminalization and other policies should be adopted.<ref>[http://ssrn.com/abstract=2396955 Cyber-Bullying in India: The Search for a Solution - Why the Current Law in India is Ill-Equipped by Mukta Batra :: SSRN<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Myspace==
*In February 2006, a 16-year-old [[Colorado]] boy was arrested for juvenile possession of a [[firearm]] after police saw pictures that he had posted on MySpace of himself posing with rifles and handguns.<ref name="rocky mountain news">{{cite news | last =Lindsay | first =Sue | title =Boy who posed with guns convicted | work =[[Rocky Mountain News]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =April 5, 2006 | url = http://www.rockymountainnews.com/drmn/local/article/0,1299,DRMN_15_4595681,00.html | accessdate = 2008-11-01 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080429072642/http://www.rockymountainnews.com/drmn/local/article/0,1299,DRMN_15_4595681,00.html |archivedate = April 29, 2008}} </ref> He was convicted in April 2006.<ref name="rocky mountain news"/>
==See also== * [[Forensic profiling]] * [[List of social networking websites]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

page.title: Wall of the Sun and Wall of the Moon

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = The Wall of the Sun<ref name=UnescoSOL>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/visit/uk/notices/miro1.htm|accessdate=28 December 2013|title=UNESCO Catalogue}}</ref> | image = Wall_of_the_Sun.jpg | artist = [[Joan Miró i Ferrà]] and [[Josep Llorens i Artigas]] | year = 1955–1958 | height_metric = 2.20 | width_metric = 15 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[UNESCO]] building | coordinates = {{coord|48|50|58|N|2|18|22|E|scale:1000_region:FR|display=inline}} }} {{Infobox artwork | title = The Wall of the Moon | artist = [[Joan Miró i Ferrà]] and [[Josep Llorens i Artigas]] | year = 1955–1958 | height_metric = 2.20 | width_metric = 7.50 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[UNESCO]] building | coordinates = {{coord|48|50|58|N|2|18|22|E|scale:1000_region:FR|display=inline}} }} The '''''Wall of the Sun''''' and '''''Wall of the Moon''''' are a pair of [[mural]]s made of ceramics and designed by the [[Catalan people|Catalan]] artist [[Joan Miró]] for the [[UNESCO]] building in Paris. The works were carried out by the ceramicist [[Josep Llorens Artigas]] in 1955.<ref name=Dupin>{{cite book|last=Dupin|first=Jacques|title=Miró|date=2004|publisher=Éditions Flammarion|location=Paris|isbn=2-0803-0450-X|page=395}}</ref> Initially, the walls were installed on the Place de Fontenoy in Paris, but afterwards were enclosed in a building that was constructed in order to protect them from damage caused by acid rain.<ref name=Unesco>{{cite web|title=The Wall of the Sun|url=http://www.unesco.org/visit/uk/notices/miro1.htm|publisher=UNESCO website|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref>
== History == [[Joan Miró]] and [[Josep Llorens Artigas]] met in 1910 at the school of art of the artist [[Francesc Galí]] (1880–1965), in Barcelona. Since the 1940s, Miró and Josep Llorens Artigas started an artistic duo that spawned objects and large ceramic murals such as one at the [[Unesco]] building in Paris or the ceramic wall of the [[Barcelona–El Prat Airport|Barcelona Airport]]. These works fused Miró lexicon with the essential qualities of the arts of earth and fire.<ref name=artigas>{{Cite web | title= Joan Gardy Artigas, Spanish (1938 - )|url=http://rogallery.com/Artigas_Joan_Gardy/artigas-biography.html| editor = rogallery.com| accessdate= 28 September 2011}}</ref>
In 1955 Joan Miró was contacted by the heads of UNESCO to ask if he want to take part of the team of artists that decorated the future headquarters of the institution that is located in Paris.<ref name=runner93>{{Cite journal|last=Corredor-Matheos|first=Josep|title=The Miró-Artigas Murals|journal=Catalonia Culture|date=October 1993|pages=34–37|volume=35}}</ref> Once agreed, they granted the exterior walls of the building conferences, two perpendicular walls of three meters high and seven meters long and fifteen, respectively. Miró proposed to make a ceramic mural in collaboration with Llorens Artigas.
In 1956, Miró began working on the mural in his studio in [[Palma, Majorca|Palma]]. The following year he went to the [[Cave of Altamira|Caves of Altamira]] in with Llorens Artigas inspired to carry on the work,<ref name="Mink2000">{{Cite book|first=Janis |last=Mink|title=Joan Miró, 1893-1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uDW3HgIw7aYC&pg=PA93|year=2000|editor=Taschen|isbn=978-3-8228-5975-9|pages=93–}}</ref><ref name="Preckler2003">{{Cite book|first=Ana María |last=Preckler|title=Historia del arte universal de los siglos XIX y XX|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJ_edWCq2UoC&pg=PA236|date= 1 January 2003|editor=Editorial Complutense|isbn=978-84-7491-707-9|pages=236–}}</ref> by seeing "the first mural in the world".<ref name=BYN59>{{Cite journal|last=Miró|first=Joan|title=Como hice los murales para la UNESCO|journal=Blanco y Negro|date=6 July 1959|volume=2457|language=Spanish}}</ref> They also visit the [[Colegiata y Claustro de Santa Juliana]] and the romanesque collection of the Museum of Art of Catalonia, the current [[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya|MNAC]].<ref name=runner93 />
=== Construction === Once inspired, Miró moved to [[Gallifa]], at the workshop of Artigas, to proceed to prepare the tile mural. It took 35 batches, 25 tons of wood, 4 tons of sandstone and 200 kilos of enamel.<ref name=runner93 /> Once finished, the pieces were transported to Paris. Although he had worked in large formats, he had never done ceramics. Beside the ceramist Josep Llorens Artigas, they failed to find technical feasibility for baking pottery in a way that allows to obtain a background textures similar to the paintings of that time.<ref>Rebull, Melania (1994) p. 65</ref> It was decided that the composition was on the subjects of "Sun" and "Moon".<ref>Malet, Rosa M. (1992) pg. 107-112</ref>
=== Inauguration === The two mosaic murals were assembled ''in situ'' by a team of technicians under the direct supervision of Miró and Llorens Artigas.<ref name=caca/> The works were inaugurated in 1958, as same as the building, and received rave reviews. Even one of the murals, the ''Wall of the Sun'' won the Biennial Prize of Guggenheim Foundation.<ref name=runner93 /><ref name=caca/> Miró later return to work for UNESCO, designing the UNESCO Medal for [[Pablo Picasso]].
=== Conservation === Initially, the walls were outdoors, but later moved inside the building to protect them from damage caused by [[acid rain]].<ref name=caca />
== Awards and recognition == * 1958 - The biennial international award of the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] for the ''Wall of the Sun''.<ref name=caca>{{Cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/es/ev.php-URL_ID=26465&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|accessdate=11 May 2014|title=Joan Miró en la UNESCO|editor=UNESCO|language=spanish}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artists/bios/11111?tmpl=component&print=1|language=catalan|accessdate=28 December 2013|title=Miró al Guggenheim|editor=Guggenheim Foundation}}</ref><ref name=Guggenheim>{{cite web|title=Joan Miró and Josep Llorens Artigas|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artists/bios/11111?tmpl=component&print=1|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Bibliography == * {{Cite book|last=Dupin|first=Jacques|title=Miró|pages=390–391|location=Barcelona|editor=Polígrafa|year=1993|isbn=84-343-0726-X}} * {{Cite book|first=Carme |last=Escudero |first2=Teresa |last2=Montaner|title=Joan Miró, desfilada d'obsessions: 14 juny-2 setembre 2001|location=Barcelona|editor=Fundació Joan Miró|year=2001|isbn=84-923925-9-2}} *{{Cite book|last=Punyet Miró |first=Joan |last2=Gardy Artigas |first2=Joan |last3= Calero |first3=Cristina |title=Joan Miró, Josep Llorens Artigas: ceramics: catalogue raisonné, 1941-1981|pages=338–399|location=Paris|editor=D. Lelong|year=2007|isbn=978-2-86882-079-2}} * {{Cite book|last=Penrose|first=Roland|title=Miró|location=London|editor=Thames and Hudson |year=1993 |isbn=84-233-1976-8 |ref=harv}}
{{Joan Miró}}
